title: Newbie Review
text: I have never played any of the 3D Mario Games and I have been gaming since the Atari 2600. I've played the original, Super Mario World, Super Mario 3 , Lost Levels etc sparingly. I can tell you the camera on Mario 64 is pretty bad. I'm getting used to it, but it's definitely showing its age. I haven't gotten into the other titles as of this review, but I hope they improve. Three games for $59.99 isn't terrible, but these aren't even ground up HD remasters; they're emulations. Don't get me wrong, they look great, and there is an improvement, but for Mario's 35th Nintendo could have done a little better. I think it is worth picking up if anything for the collectors aspect of a limited physical release.

title: Fantastic Collection of Classic 3D Super Mario Games
text:
Whether you grew up playing these games or not, they are certainly presented here in their very best formats (with the exception of running Dolphin), that to say some of the obtuse controls and camera angles cannot prevent the first two from showing their age some. Despite this their importance in the 3D platforming genre remains and they are still as much fun to play now as they were then.

Yeah extras would have been nice, but knowing Nintendo and their tendencies to keep these kind of releases pretty dry I wasn't very surprised. The album availabilities are a nice addition, and if you purchased the digital set you're eligible for the "My Nintendo" Super Mario 35th Anniversary enamel pin set (sure to be a collector item).

If you've enjoyed Super Mario Odyssey, just know that Super Mario 64 served as the blueprints for that open world adventure, necessary polygon building blocks to set up future Mario greatness. While plenty of reviewers here will whine and complain (as expected) It's a practical must have for the Nintendo fan in you, and since it's apparently a timed release (gone March 2021) Nintendo is all but making sure you MUST have it.

title: Nostalgic
text: I have been having SO much fun with this! On the title screen, you can select what game you want to play OR listen to the soundtrack for any of the three games. Once you select your game, it transports you to the “main menu” of the game you selected. So far, the modifications to the Switch have been great and just take a little adjusting. Mario 64 is still a little janky with the controls and I wish you could edit/modify them, but you cannot. However, the controls were always a little odd so it’s not a surprise. Still able to navigate it and complete the levels. I’ve been having a LOT of fun and am shocked with how much I remember about these games from my childhood! Would recommend if you enjoy these games or have any interest in this set—especially since Nintendo said it’s a limited release game (selling until the end of March I believe).

title: Great compilation of classic games with faults
text:
My review is not for the games themselves all three are great and they play well here. There’s really no need to talk about them. My review is more so the way Nintendo handled this release with a “limited” window. Also the PAL cart looks much better than the ntsc. Go and search it you’ll see what I mean. My biggest gripe with this is there is no ability to change controls or any sort of additional features to the games which would be standard for any sort of compilation like this. In particular sunshine, I’m an invert Y player yet there is no ability to do this. Makes the game such a pain. Which I’m sure could be fixed in an update to add those features but we know it won’t happen.

I love these three games but truthfully for what was presented a 60 dollar package this is not. Should have been maybe 10 per title. If they did the basics like control mapping and some kind of online functionality this would have been 60 for sure.

title: Lotsa fun
text:
Lazy Nintendo emulator cash grab, and pointless limited release aside, I’m having a lot of fun with this collection. Honestly I’d pay the money just for Galaxy, which is my favorite Mario so far. I have fond memories of being in absolute awe when I first played it on the wii back in the day. It works well with the detached joycons to use the motion controls the way it was meant to be played.

Mario 64 is here too, and that takes me back to the good ole days. I never did beat Mario 64 that I can recall, so looking forward to finally getting around to that.

Mario sunshine I never played more than the intro on the GameCube. Of the 3, this is the one that excites me the least, but after I beat the other 2 I’ll def give it a go. I’ve played a bit and I noticed they ditched the ridiculous inverted controls, which is good for me. I’m sure some people are going to be upset that there is no apparent way to switch it back.

My major gripe, if I have to have one, is the collectible pin set that was supposed to be available to everyone that bought the game. Even though they made clear that this was a “while supplies last” kind of thing, I expected supplies to last for more than an hour. On the first day they were made available, they were no longer available, which means they may have had a few hundred or a thousand sets of these, if that. They probably paid enough for a minimum quantity production run from the factory and called it a day, not caring how many people they would disappoint. Yes I’m a 32 year old man and I’m pissed about a retarded Chinese-made pin set, lol. Seriously, gone within and hour? This was just salt in the wound after the lazy full priced half-port of decades old games.

title: Great game, not a great version
text:
The game is great, of course. There is more to do to keep you busy than ever before.

Unfortunately on the Switch the game does not work very well. Perhaps it doesn't have enough processing power to do all the generation? I have no idea, but the game crashes or randomly gets stuck loading and needs to be force-quit. Even when it's working correctly, the load times are pretty long. Then there will be bugs where destroyed blocks don't disappear.

It's playable if you can get a really good deal on it, but as this is the most expensive version of the Bedrock game, I would strongly recommend getting it on a different platform. It's not like this is a brand new game on the switch so clearly there are some systemic issues with the platform for this game.

title: Extremely bare bones collection with mostly lazy ports
text: Super Mario Galaxy runs at 1080p 60fps, and is the most technically advanced game in the collection. So why is it that Mario 64 runs at 720p 30fps and Sunshine runs at 1080p 30fps? The Switch can easily handle all three games at 1080p 60fps. There's also some audio lag issues in Mario 64.  There are no additional levels or characters like in the DS Mario 64 remake, no new unlockable levels, no concept art, interviews, or anything like that aside from the ability to listen to the songs from the games on the main menu. Even the menu looks cheap. Nintendo definitely didn't care about making this a true celebration of Mario, just a celebration of the windfall of money going into their pockets.

title: Same Old Games - For Better and Worse
text:
Buyers will not get a truly updated version of any of these, and the gameplay mechanics that didn't age well (camera of 64 and physics of Sunshine) did not get any meaningful updates.

After beating all of them on this collection, Galaxy is still the best so long as you like the features of it (i.e. upside down, sideways, etc. physics). The gyroscopic features are far better with the joy-cons instead of the old Wii remote limitations.

Sunshine is still frustrating in many ways due to its physics, and 64 has aged very poorly, including a broken camera system that could have been updated for the modern controls to allow for better control.

Overall, it's nice to get 3 classics in one, with 1 that hasn't had a true rerelease since the Gamecube, but you are not getting any meaningful updates with this one, for better and worse.

title: Childhood Revisited
text:
Three great Mario classics in one title. Nintendo did a good job porting these titles, the graphics are clean and sharp, and the controls are intuitive despite using different button layouts than were available on the original N64 / Gamecube / Wii. You do lose some functionality in the translation, for example, the switch joycons lack pressure sensitivity, however this only marginally affects game play and is far from a deal breaker.

I also like how they included the music library of all three games in a separate music player which allows you to listen with the screen off conserving battery.

If you grew up with these classics or want to introduce them to a new generation, definitely pick this up before Nintendo pulls it from shelves next Spring!

title: Way better than the lackluster Pocket Edition
text:
Works great and saves progress great, even without an internet connection! Way more features than the wimpy and small "M:PE" (Minecraft Pocket Edition) we had several years ago. Much more caves and places to explore, much more flowers and craft-able items.

Update: This game gets lonely and boring when all the villagers have disappeared/turned into zombies - without respawning as normal villagers. How can you respawn/create new villagers in single player Survival Mode? If currently impossible, please fix this. I would like some new edible plants in the updates: Green Tea plants, various types of rice (especially sushi rice and mochi rice), and edible oak/maple leaves (kashiwa-mochi with oak leaf and mochi, and momiji-tempura - fried maple leaves). And other new food updates: Hotcakes/pancakes, fruit/veggie juices and sushi.

title: Just an software emulated ROM without any new fixes
text:
Bought it mainly to relive my early teenage Super Mario 64 years on a modern 1080P TV. The picture is nice and sharp. Though it would have been nice if they fixed the "smoke bug", when Mario catches on fire the wrong animation is shown due to a coding error. Was later found and fixed by gaming community. Look it up on youtube. It would've only taken a few mins to change one line on the source code. Also all three games are software emulated instead of having a proper port (guess Nintendo just wanted to milk our nostalgia for $60 without actually working for it). On the plus side though, the game runs at 60 fps compared to ~30 fps when SM64 was running on an actually N64.

Being a limited time release, I guess Nintendo desperately wanted nostalgic fans to take the $60 dive quickly before gamers started to realize that this was just a rushed Emulated ROM cash grab without the small improvements.

title: Great for nostalgia, mediocre otherwise
text:
One of the other reviews I read speculated Nintendo said "What's the minimum amount of work we can do to port this to the switch?" and I agree with that. Granted the controllers are different, but they barely adjusted the in game instructions. The in game prompts still had images of previous controllers and during tutorials they just said to "Press the button" instead of saying "Press the Z button".

I'm still happy I bought it.

title: 3 games in ONE and play anywhere you want!
text: What can I say? You're getting three amazing classic mario games for the price of 1 and on top of that, you can play anywhere you want on the go. If you're expecting this copy is going to include a whole bunch of goodies such as the history, artwork, etc. Then you will be MAJORLY disappointed. This copy is just 3 games and thats it! The only added feature this collection has is the ability to hear the soundtrack from all 3 games. Lastly, Super Mario Galaxy 2 is NOT included. Some people think Galaxy 2 is hidden somewhere or can be unlocked by doint something but sadly that is not the case. It truly is baffling that Nintendo didn't include Galaxy 2. Then again, this IS nintendo after all. Nintendo has a record of releasing questionable games like this and not bothering to add a bit more flair to them in order to celebrate the history of the games.

title: No Tutorial, No Instructions
text:
I was excited to finally try Minecraft with my 8-year-old son. I figured that with all the hype, even though the graphics are so SO ugly to me, we would find it fun. We loaded it up. There is no tutorial world in this edition, and no instructions. Within 2 minutes he got stuck in a bush and couldn't get out. So I tried starting my own game. Within 5 minutes I got stuck in a small fenced garden. Game over.

I suppose we could spend a long afternoon watching and reading tutorials, but with this game (version) being so unhelpful, I think we're just going to return it. I'm also expecting legions of superfans to vote this down, but maybe they should consider that whatever version they first played it on years ago, it probably had a tutorial of some kind.

title: 3 great games with some caviats
text: this collection contains 3 games from Mario's past that were amazing, super Mario 64 was a revolutionary game for its time bringing in amazing 3d graphics for the time which was 1996 and ultimately brought gaming into the 3d era. super Mario sunshine is a weird but ultimately cult classic that has aged tremendously well, Mario galaxy is an incredible classic that brings Mario's adventures to space. the problem occurs when you realize that they did not remaster the graphics at all and took an approach similar to old movie releases like the terminator or lion king animated and especially the Pixar movies (I wish they would remaster toy story 1-3 with toy story 4 visuals), and for a video game it is a weird approach. and with the limited-time release, you could say Nintendo is taking the Disney vault approach when it comes to there classic games with no word if they are going to rerelease these games on a virtual console containing N64 - GameCube - Wii mainly because the WII u port well is running dry. and sadly galaxy 2 is not included in this and just like Disney censored the racism in the original fantasia. I do think if this collection was released on a later console that Mario Odyssey would be part of the collection. ultimately though if you want to relive your childhood or if you want to experience 1 or 2 or all 3 for the first time then I do think this would be a good buy, and I do think that I would give this 3.5 stars out of 5 but because amazon won't let me do that because the games are actually good I am giving this collection a 4 out of 5 stars

title: Having played all of these when they were originally released, this was a super cool compilation
text:
I loved each of these when they were originally released. Seeing them all on the same cartridge for the Switch, I knew I had to have them. While they are high def ports of the original three games, they still definitely slightly show their age. They're progressively more difficult but every stage has its own mechanic to make it seem fresh and fun. I just wish they could've fit Super Mario Galaxy 2 on it to round them all out.

For years I've had the Super Mario Sunshine music stuck in my head, and if you're like me, this will do NOTHING to help stop that. It's just such a great soundtrack!

If you're like me and you love the challenge of the older school 3d Mario platforming (the optional challenge levels in Sunshine were some of the absolutely maddeningly hard platforming I've EVER experienced, and I've played Super Meat Boy through to the end!), then don't hesitate to try to grab this while you can.

title: Unplayable due simply to camera controls
text:
I got this out of nostalgia and was excited to replay old classic Mario games I grew up on. All 3 titles are unplayable as-is. I bought this digitally, not on Amazon. Rating it here anyway as a warning to others.

Mario 64 -- camera angles are infuriating and nausea inducing. The buttons, as others have mentioned, make no sense and are clunky. Too many buttons are re-used for different functions and it's impossible to play.

Sunshine -- you can't invert the y axis. This is 100% a deal breaker. The water controls are a ***nightmare***.

Highly disappointed. What a lazy and half-baked first party video game port.

title: Yeah!
text:
I bought a switch for this game. My family is obsessed with Mario Kart. We upgraded from a Wii.

Good:
Graphics are nice/cute. Game is MUCH easier than the Wii version. They have some features which keep you turned the right direction and when the race starts you get an initial boost. Our daughter who struggled to finish races is now in 6th place.

I like that they revamped some old tracks. I like that they are releasing new tracks. I did my homework so I knew half the new tracks aren’t unlocked yet.

Online play is fun, but slightly soul crushing.

Love the vehicle customization options.

Love that you can pick how many races you want to do.

Bad:
Game is glitchy.

Sometimes steering is a little off.

Often enemies will appear right in front of you where before they didn’t exist (yes worse than the Wii.)

Races seem a lot shorter.

Tracks change the second and third time through. Meh.

Not enough characters.

Overall wish they had spent some more time on it. I feel like this has become one of Nintendo’s core games so it should have been a knock out and not feel glitchy. Plus like… it’s a super expensive game with online access required to unlock levels so I feel like it should be near perfect.

Overall recommend this game to anyone that has kids or likes Mario Kart. Leaves a lot to be desired but still very fun.

title: Great compilation!

title: Welcome to Lag City
text:
I bought this for my kids knowing nothing about Minecraft other than it's something a lot of kids like. And they love it! They'd play it all day, every day if we'd let them. I have not played Minecraft on any other platforms than the Switch. It's not a secret that the Switch is certainly lacking in processing power and graphics capability compared to other modern consoles or PC's, but it is very limiting to Minecraft.

My issues with at least the Switch version is how bad it bogs down. Once you get a decent amount built on a world, it becomes so laggy it's unplayable. Actions don't do anything, nothing spawns, the game locks up, you can't get in your inventory, etc. I can't fathom how a 40 MB file can do this on a modern system, but it sure does. A Google search shows this is a pretty common issue on Switch, and there was nothing to do about it but basically delete all the saved data and start over, and the developers haven't done anything to patch it to where it will consistently run on Switch.

title: Purchased because it's a limited release.
text: This is a cool collection, especially if people have never played these games. The controls are not very well done at times, and I already owned these games, so they were pretty expensive for what you get.

title: Could've been better
text:
This is not a commentary on the games themselves which are amazing classics that exemplify the best of the platforming genre but mere a rating on the collection as compared to other collections.

The timed release thing is sketchy and downright manipulative, the extras are nonexistent, and the content is sorely lacking for the price.

Let's compare this collection to emulation: with emulation 64 and Sunshine can go at 60 fps with better formatting for widescreen. This collection does none of that. With emulation you can mod 64 to look great much in the same way the first all-stars collection improved the graphics of the first three games.
Barebones, lazy, and disrespectful for a franchise that is such a critical and commercial darling.

Now let's compare it to other compilations:
Crash N'Sane trilogy and Spyro Reignited both have three games each but they come with amazing graphical enhancements and a far more reasonable price of $40.00.

This collection also misses so many other Mario games. Why isn't the sequel to Mario Galaxy in the collection? Or Super Mario 3D world? Or Super Mario Oddyssey?

I purchased this product only because I never properly experienced Sunshine if you have played all these three games I would recommend you spend your money elsewhere but if not it's a good enough place to start especially if you get Switch Online so you can play Super Mario All-Stars.

title: This is the most lazy first-party port I've ever seen
text:
Nintendo made this a MASSIVE deal. I was very excited to play it, until I realized that it is just like the classics...….. Except much, much worse. When a third party emulator plays these games 10 times better than the switch does, it really tells you how much effort Nintendo put into this "port".

Super Mario 64
- The game plays in a little square in the middle of the screen. Why did they not make this widescreen? It runs at 30fps, but somehow there are frame drops when there are more than 5 enemies on the screen. How are there frame drops in a 24 year old game? The controls are also unmappable, and they inverted them from the original.

Super Mario Sunshine
- Very buggy, controls inverted from the original, on screen it tells you to hit the wrong buttons (they didn't change the original text to tell you to hit the buttons that are compatible with the Nintendo switch)…. Oh..... and since the switches controllers have analog triggers, you can't control water pressure. This never should have made its way to the switch in its current rushed state.

Super Mario Galaxy
- The joy cons are not as accurate for pointing as the Wii mote. This makes it extremely hard to collect stars, and you have to hit the recalibrate button every 10-15 seconds. Also, there is no alternative to motion controls or touchscreen controls so you will always be uncomfortable playing this.

Don't make the mistake I made and jump the gun on this one. For $60, in the games current state it doesn't make sense. Unless Nintendo makes some huge changes to the way the games run, I would pass on this one.

text:
I looked forward to getting the switch version of Minecraft to be able to play while mobile in a better format than with a phone or tablet. Big mistake. This game crashes almost everytime I try to play, usually before the game is even loaded.

I didn't expect a completely standalone console experience with Nintendo's underpowered semi-handheld, but usually the crashes happen before loading an actual world. Sometimes in the middle of exploring or mining, so good luck getting back your progress!

The autosave system will sometimes deign to do it's job, but only when the game feels like it's warranted. The draw distance is pitiful, and the framerate drops even in survival. Spend your money on a mpre powerful edition, like ps3 or 360, or heck, mobile.

title: We used to play Nintendo.  Nintendo played us on this one....
text:
Sorely disappointed in this... usually Nintendo is pretty good about their titles... and particularly the ones that are reissued.   This one,  however, is a pretty obvious cash grab with very little effort put into it.   It started by creating a frenzy by stating its a "limited run in physical copies"... something not entirely new to those familiar with switch titles.  That served as a fine distraction from what is really going on.... the fact that Nintendo didn't put any effort into this.   First... the major complaints I had with Mario64 in its original release were the controls and the camera system.  I thought perhaps I could look past that for upgrade graphics... but honestly we don't even get that. We get what they say is increased resolution... but honestly doesn't look much better.  And they slapped us square in the face (square...pun intended)  with the fact that it's STILL 4:3 aspect ratio. A friend said "that's really difficult to convert to HD 16:9".  Okay... for you and me.. sure... but this is Nintendo.... the often-proven kings of that game... and for sixty bucks.... do SOMETHING with it.... please?  Add to that the fact that it's a straight port.... the camera controls are (still) garbage.... and the controls themselves are (still)  in the can with the camera.... and what you've got is a slightly improved resolution on a nearly 25 year old game.  My advice? If you're playing 64 on this platform,  set your TV to "stretch".  With the upped resolution...its "almost" bearable. 

Mario Galaxy was the one title of the three of never played.  It looks pretty decent,  graphics wise,  but be forewarned...if you're a pro controller die-hard like me... you're in for a rude awakening.  Multiple news sources stated that WOULD be an option to play without motion controls..And it ALMOST is true. Motion controls are not required...in handheld mode.   In TV mode... no option.... even with a pro controller you have to use motion controls... and that's just clunky as hell... The better option is to play with joy-cons.... but i absolutely, morbidly despise Joy Cons. They are the bane of my existence.   And I don't play in handheld mode.  So, if you're like me... docked and a pro- controller user...There's no way to play without motion controls.  Not acceptable to me... especially given the horribly misleading news prior to release stating the contrary.  If someone figures out that I'm wrong... and can tell me how to do that... I'll listen. But it's not obvious if it's, indeed,  available as an option.

The standout here is Sunshine.   It's flawless.  It's pro-controller compatible,  looks great in upped resolution,  and plays great as well.   So,  basically I paid 60  dollars for a straight port of Sunshine... and soundtracks I could find on YouTube.  If you're good with a misleading release campaign,  an underwhelming effort by Nintendo to make any of these much better than the originals... and soundtracks... jump on and have fun.  

Me?  I stand firmly in the "shame on you Nintendo" crowd.

title: Great collection of games
text: Some of the finest 3D platforming games made by any standard, and some of the best games of their respective generations. Sunshine in particular gets the most noticeable facelift with 1080p when docked and widescreen mode, and the game looks fantastic in mobile and on a Switch lite. For those who will inevitably ask about it, ZR is the default soft pressure nozzle which can be used while running, and R is the hard pressure nozzle for stand-still aiming. Sunshine also packs a significant challenge and demands your precision. Mario Galaxy already looked amazing and looks even better, its a full 1080p with 60 FPS (Mario Sunshine is 30 FPS like the original is). Some people may claim this should be cheaper, but one can argue a game like Mario Sunshine alone is over $60 dollars online.  It's a fantastic, collectible package that offers many hours of near-perfect gameplay.

title: Great Games Poor Customization.
text: The games included are great in their own right, but lack customization and features expected in a quality re-released emulated title. The games play great and are smooth, but the package is kind of underwhelming in its presentation. The controls for galaxy don't feel as natural or satisfying as the Wii, but they get the job done and is a small price to pay to experience the game in its native texture resolutions for the first time. The absence of Super Mario Galaxy 2 is a stab in the gut. It's clear Nintendo plans on milking us further for yet another old title to be polished slightly then priced as a new original $60 title. That combined with the fact that the digital edition will also be fazed out with the hard copies scream anti-consumer as they will most likely be using this false scarcity to boost short-time sales while still being able to charge full price for these games years later when they decide to reintroduce them. If you love these titles, buy the game. If you could care less and want to combat this anticonsumer strategy I'd pass on this one as there is nothing fundamentally new added to the experience that you can't achieve through emulation of your other owned copies.

title: Too much luck. Little focus on skill.
text:
So many flaws. You could do literally everything perfect sometimes and still lose because of getting hit with a blue shell at the last second. It's especially annoying when you should have had a much larger lead. If you watch the A.I you can see they're not very skilled but somehow they're always right behind you. When they're in front of you it's impossible to predict what box they're gonna get because they move side to side in random directions. In 200cc it you need to press the brake but the A.I doesnt need to. I read that in the first mario kart it was extra hard because instead of making intelligent A.I racers they just gave them unfair advantages. They are still just as lazy well over 20 years later. I don't mind losing if it's fair but its extremely frustrating when you did nothing wrong. Also the vehicle strengths and weaknesses are inaccurate. I choose a vehicle that was better than the one I use and it had less control even though it said it has better traction and control. Another bs addition is making you pay to play online. This was free on wii. All the unlockable stuff is worthless. You would think everytime you unlock a vehicle it would be better than the last one but it's not. If you beat every level you get gold mario but he's not better than the other characters. I would say the worst thing about the game is getting hit with 4 things in a row and going from first place to last place. This goes back to a point I made earlier. Not only should u not be able to get hit that many times in a row but most times it makes no sense that everybody is right behind you even though u've driven perfect. As I said earlier losing isn't that frustrating but losing when it makes no sense is extremely frustrating. Especially when to get 3 gold stars u have to finish 1st in 4 races in a row. Out of these 4 races some bs is bound to happen on one of the tracks which ruins your 3 gold stars. And yet another flaw, after that bs happens, you can't just retry the race. You have to start all 4 races from the beginning. And with 200cc it's not fun. You have to constantly press the brake(some tracks are more annoying than others) and ot doesn't make sense in terms of physics. Whether you're going super fast or just starting off you have the same crappy control. Sometimes you get stuck against the wall even when pressing the brake. Another thing that is absurd is the boost you get when driving behind people. If everybody is driving close together you'll get a boost you dont want that sometimes sends you flying off the edge in levels like rainbow road. Again this is especially frustrating because it's sometimes unavoidable and not your fault. Also on levels like rainbow road I end up in first place only getting mushroom boosts that you cant even use because of the lack of straight track. I'm sure there's more flaws I haven't thought of but I'll leave it at that for now.

Since I included so many flaws ill also list some positives....
-solid graphics for a mario kart game
-i like that there's 2 ways to stop the blue shell
-until you reach 200cc, drifting is pretty fun when you master it
-decent amount of levels, even though they use old levels to make it seem like there's more levels than there really is(this goes back to them being lazy like with cheating A.I drivers). I like playing older levels but there should be more new ones.
-good amount of characters to choose from
-rain looks pretty cool
Just like the flaws there is probably some positives I'm forgetting

title: My Nostalgic Story and Review
text:
I am 26 years old. (27 after two days I posted this review) Most of you who have this game understand completely why these three Mario games were some of best during your childhood. I'm one of those people. Now I understand people can play these already from some emulated port for PC, but it feels wonderful to finally see more throwback 3d games from previous Nintendo consoles on to the Switch.

I was screaming when Sunshine showed up in the collection. As a kid in the early 2000s, It was actually my 2rd most frequently played video game during the GameCube Era. Mario64 was okay, I haven't really played that much on the 64 due to the cartridge kept getting dirty and causing it to freeze too often. Of course I had no idea how to properly clean it back then. As for the Mario Galaxy, I never owned the Wii but my niece sure did. When she first got it on Christmas and showed me the game-play, I was completely invested. I even took over her Wii just for that purpose. What a horrible Uncle I am, but she didn't mind.

Real talk about the three games. All of them resembles as an album of respected Mario titles that were well praised in their respective console eras. It also tells the next generation of gamers how our gen feels about these 3 particular titles. Now would love to give an all out 5 Star review to this but I wish they added a little more features in the main collection menu. The complete soundtrack is nice and all, but I was hoping they would add some rough/finished concept artwork, sketches and maybe even some fan-art back in those eras. I would like to see some personal interviews with the Lead Developers and Designers of the 3 games. Koji Kondo would really surprise me.

Overall, I love it and there's no way I'm ever going give or sell this game to anyone for as long as I live.

Thank You Nintendo! :)

title: Three Classic Mario Games In One Great Package
text:
A fantastic bundle. Three of the most classic 3D Mario games ever made in one package. Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine, and Super Mario Galaxy, plus their soundtracks, all in one. Here are a few things to know going into it:

- Super Mario 64 runs at 720p 30 FPS, up from 240p. (Docked)

- Super Mario Sunshine runs at 1080p 30 FPS, up from 480p. (Docked)

- Super Mario Galaxy runs at 1080p 60 FPS, up from 720p 30 FPS. (Docked)

- This is the updated version of Super Mario 64, that fixes the backwards long jump glitch and removes some voice lines from Mario I.E. "So long, King Bowser!"

- You are not able to change the camera options in Super Mario Sunshine, you can however change the controller settings outside of the game if this is a big enough issue for you. However there is nothing you can do for the lack of analog triggers. I didn't see this as much of an issue personally.

- These are NOT remakes. A few textures are updated here and there, and the UI is updated where is needed, but overall this will be the exact same experience you played through the first time, at upgraded resolutions.

- You can turn your screen off while listening to the soundtrack, which is a great feature for listening in bed or on the go.

Overall this is a great package, so long as you know what you are getting. Temper your expectations if you were expecting a full remaster, because that's not what you'll find. You will find a great collection of classic Mario games that play the way they should and look acceptably good.

title: Enjoyable but frustrating
text: As somebody who only grew up with Mario Galaxy 2, and played the old ones on emulator. I was excited to see that Nintendo was giving fans a chance to relive the glory days of 3D Mario on their newest and dare I say most popular console, the Nintendo Switch ( not to say the new games are bad, the old ones just have a certain magic to them ). I honestly don't know what I expected. The controls are a bit weird to get used to, ( especially in Mario 64 and Sunshine ) but to me that's excusable considering 64 and Sunshine are quite "ancient", if you want to describe it that way. One gripe I do have is the camera, something just feels wrong about it even though these are supposed to be direct ports, maybe I'm not used to the actual camera since emulators can slightly change things, so I'll leave that to your own discernment if you buy this game. Now, I do have two issues with this game. One major issue I personally have is that Nintendo went out of their way to remove some of the most iconic glitches in these games, most notably the back wards long jump, which allows for some fun glitches and antics inside of the game. As someone who enjoys speed runs, I can't exactly see why Nintendo did this, as a casual player would probably be too lazy/too ignorant to abuse these glitches, while the old fans and speedrunners would appreciate Nintendo not patching these glitches out. Heck, it might have even reignited a passion and popularity for speed running these games as old speedrunners could move to upgraded hardware and new speedrunners could simply buy this game and start their career of speedrunning 64, Sunshine, and Galaxy, boosting sales of not only Nintendo switches and this game, and possibly eliminate the need to support Nintendo's greatest enemy, emulation. For me it was a missed opportunity to kind of redeem Nintendo's social status and have them reconnect with their player base since they haven't been the exactly been greatest and consumer friendly company the last 2 years. The second gripe I have is a minor one, and that is Nintendo's motion support for the pro controller in galaxy. Thankfully, Nintendo was smart enough to keep the cursor reset button but still it's a pain to use the pro controller, and I don't think anybody wants to use the barely functional joy-cons. Regardless of my complaints, I still think this is a great title worthy of buying to gift for somebody who has recently become a fan of the Mario series/long time fan/new switch owner.

title: Awesome!  Super Mario 64 is still the best 3D Mario to this day!
text:
This whole collection is awesome and Super Mario 64 is still #1 when it comes to 3D Mario games. It's awesome being able to play all these games on a handheld. I love how mysterious the castle of Mario 64 is. Going to where the Hazy Maze Cave areas are and where you go to drain the castle moat. The whole atmosphere is a part of why I love it so much. I love castles and I love how there's this black hole where the balls roll into in Hazy Maze Cave, the horizontal elevator and the music where you find Dorrie is really awesome. I love the waterfall outside the castle and the pole jumping inside the volcano in the Lethal Lava Land and Dire Dire Docks. The Secret Aquarium. So many, many things that make this the best, too many to list!!

Super Mario Sunshine and Galaxy are awesome too, even though some parts of Sunshine feels more like work. The cleaning up with FLUDD just feels like work but most of the game is really cool. Also, I really love the music in Galaxy. A lot of it is orchestrated and I love how they have the airship music from SMB3 in this remixed. I love all three main themes of these games: castle, tropical and space.

I love this collection and highly recommend it!

title: Wonderful Memories in SD Brought Back to Life in HD
text:
I was beyond ecstatic when Nintendo announced this collection. Barebones? Yes, it is at times. It would have been great to see the games rebuilt from the ground up, or remastered in their original format with additional flourishes regarding graphics and imagery. At times, it seems like Nintendo just hit a button labeled UPSCALE GRAPHICS and poof! This game popped out. I am disappointed? Absolutely NOT! I'd rather have this than nothing.

Mario 64 is probably the one that really needs to be built from the ground up again, but it is fine the way it is because this is how it originally was. Gamers that never experienced this game back in the 90s because they weren't born yet shouldn't immediately dismiss it. This is a true masterpiece and it was amazing to see such a huge leap from 2D to 3D done right. The camera can be a bit janky at time, but still a great game regardless.

Sunshine and Galaxy look amazing. It is probably the best they will ever look unless Nintendo decides to do a hardcore 4K HD remaster. Everything is upscaled and the visuals looks crisp, sharp, and clear. Great to have these games is HD and happy to have them play on a modern day flat screen TV without red, white, and yellow cords. Yes, you can use the pro controller (thank goodness) for Galaxy, but when certain touchscreen options come on screen, there is no other option but to remove it from dock mode.

I do wish the DS and Wii New Super Mario Bros 2D games were on here along with Mario Galaxy 2, and New Super Mario Land 3D from the 3DS. I hope these games will be considered for a future collection release. Pick this and support them You won't be disappointed. These are all masterpieces and true treasures. A mascot that has been in the game for 3 plus decades, and the best he'll ever look for a modern day console. Just what we needed during a pandemic.

title: Get it now, while you can!
text: Many people know this already, but in case you don't, this is a time-limited release. That means it won't be available for long. The digital version of this game on the Nintendo e-shop is also time-limited. After the deadline, they will be pulling it off the shop. So grab this physical copy while you can! It will be a nice showcase on your game shelf. For the price, getting 3 amazing Mario games in one package, all of which have been updated to look "better" on an HD TV. Mario 64 still has the worst camera ever, but nostalgia and challenge are there. Sunshine and Galaxy look amazing and smooth. The main menu of the game also has the ability to listen to each game's soundtrack.

So, Nintendo stops selling digital copies immediately on March 31st 2021. Production of the physical copies have stopped, so it'll only get tougher to get the game through legit means. I decided that since I know I love 2 of the offered 3 titles, it was well worth $49.99. It's already gone up to $70 and I do not see it getting any lower.

If you can get past that then by all means these are the games for you but if you have a hard time with aiming and centering stuff, or control that go one way and not the way you're actually pointing, or you get dizzy playing games these are a hard pass

title: A fantastic Mario package for the Switch
text:
This collection doesn't have much to it aside from these three games and their soundtracks but honestly that is already one incredible package. This is also the fastest Switch game to boot up it's almost seamless from home to game which is pretty impressive. I will do a quick breakdown of each game and if they are superior to the original

Mario 64 is a touch up of the Shindou version, this means it has some bug fixes but most importantly or at least the one change that stands out the most is Mario says "bye bye" when throwing bowser as oppose to "so long king bowser" overall, this is a great version to play but keep in mind it's the only game of this collection running at 30FPS

Mario Sunshine is dressed up very nicely here and is running at a smooth 60 FPS 1080p but it does feel a bit weird to me. This might be a me thing as I didn't play much sunshine in the past but it's definitely a much better version of the game than the original as far as visuals and gameplay.

Mario Galaxy has to be the best it's ever been here, once again 60FPS and 1080 the controls work great whether you are using the joy cons, the pro controller, or handheld. I will admit, handheld might be the least intuitive out of the three as you need to touch the screen to collect starbits. However, the Switch version added your spin attack as it's own button now, which is really nice to have the only motion needed is for collecting bits

Overall, awesome collection and I would love to see more of these from Nintendo

text:
Millennial Boomer here, as one I need to admit I skipped the past three generations of Nintendo. I was too busy with life. This release gives me the ability to play the Mario games that I missed out on. I have to say this collection is pretty solid And one of my favorite Parts is being able to play each Games soundtrack.
The photos I'm adding are ones that they don't use in the ad. The back of the case and the inside of the case. Hopefully this small quick review helped.

title: Bare minimum effort.
text:
While recent patches have added a few options, such as inverted camera controls, and GameCube controller support, the rest of the package is basically a bare minimum effort. The "All-Stars" namesake bears little resemblance to the outstanding SNES compilation it borrows from. There's a couple minor updates (Mario 64 has a handful of higher resolution textures, including the typeface), but for the most part these are the original games running on in-house emulation, as opposed to native ports. Most players won't notice.

If this is all you're expecting, and you don't consider Mario Galaxy 2 missing to be a problem, you won't be disappointed. But if the 'All-Stars' name suggests a little something extra to celebrate Mario's prior 3D adventures, you're looking in the wrong place.

title: They could have done a lot better with little effort.
text:
It's kind of fun and cool to have these games on the SWITCH for portable play, but the set feels super meh.

Overall it feels like you are playing the games on a bare bones emulator set to about mid-quality, nothing nearly as good as the ones they are using for their online classic service. Overall wouldn't buy again, nor recommend. I bought it out of pure super Mario fanboy excitement. All my friends waited to play my copy before buying and they all said the same thing, "They cheeped out so much on this I don't even want to support this kind of thing. This is worth $15 at most, not $50+" .

text:
I never played any of these 3 games until the purchase of this game cart. I've also never owned the original consoles for which these games initially debuted. While many in the comments will give their opinions based on specifications and nostalgia, I basically am giving this review as someone looking at this with fresh eyes/hands.

Super Mario 64: it looks fine but the 3rd person camera placement is difficult to work with. The graphics are solidly outdated, but if you've never played before, the mechanics aren't terrible. It's "good for what it is", which is basically my way of saying that I might come back to it later. I had similar camera troubles with Ocarina of Time for the 3DS. I think I may just be too old to go back to this one.

Super Mario Sunshine: the idea of having Mario/Princes/Character dialogue is interesting, but a little off-putting. The game itself is pretty fun. Unlike Mario U or 3DLand (mostly side scrolling), the worlds/levels feels far more open. The mechanics took some time to get used to both docked and undocked, but I can say that I enjoyed playing this game. It feels like a not-mario Mario game. In some ways I can see Breath of the Wild having been influenced by some design aspects of this game in particular.

Super Mario Galaxy: I'm still getting used to this one, but it's a very fun game and graphically and gameplay wise a bit more interesting as well as advanced. This one I haven't beaten, but I think I would already like to play the follow-up game as well (I hear it's quite good). This is probably the best of the 3, though I do enjoy Sunshine.

Both of the latter play in full screen docked which is nice. Mario 64 seems to clip on the screen. This might be another reason why I'm irked by it (besides the camera work).

In all I think $60 is good for both Sunshine and Galaxy combined as I had never played them before. But if you have played them previously, as well as 64, $60 is a probably bit steep. I feel like for this price, Nintendo could have leveled-up/refined the graphics somewhat. But it is what it is and I can at least play this on the go.

5 stars for trying to put 3 games in one cart.
2 stars for not bothering to update graphics.
5 stars for the fun of Galaxy and Sunshine.
1 star for Mario 64. It really feels half hearted.
3 stars for controls being a little strange.

I would give it 3.5 stars, but I guess rounding up to the whole star is what I'll do, so 4 stars.

title: Online doesn't work, Nether portals don't either
text:
We have the Minecraft Bedrock edition for PC, PE (android devices), and Switch. PC and PE have worked great. No complaints or problems. On the Switch has been an entirely different story.

The game freezes and crashes sometimes during gameplay. This is infrequent, but a real pain.

Worse, it recently started almost always freezes the entire Switch, requiring a hard reboot, when signing in to play on Minecraft Realms. It also constantly loses its connection to a microsoft profile, so you constantly have to redo this broken horrible process.

Then the kicker is Nether portals don't always work. Which is honestly even worse than only working sometimes. My son got trapped in the Nether because a portal worked going into the Nether, and didn't going back to the overworld. I had to break the Nether portal and rebuild it differently, then it worked. But now he can't use the same portal from the overworld that used to work, even after restarting the game. From reading online, this bug has existed for at least 3 years.

title: Probably a hard pass unless you're here for nostalgia
text:
I'm only familiar with Mario 1-4 and Odyssey and a couple other 2d games from the series. Love old games and platinum'd Meat Boy, Sekiro, and nearly Death Stranding so I'm used to hard and frustrating, but holy cow 64 and Sunshine need quality of life updates BAD.
Played a bit of Mario 64 and had to stop because the camera is just awful and it has not aged well. Unless you're already really familiar I just don't see anyone enjoying it unless you REALLY like kinda clunky 3d platformers
I'm 33 stars into Sunshine and it's just such a slog getting kicked to the main area every single time you die that I'm already getting tired of it.
L1 brings up a map which has a 3 second animation to open and close every time you accidentally press it trying to long jump or whatever.
long unskippable cutscenes, slow text boxes
Your fludd nozzle gets changed anytime you go anywhere so i tend to fall to my death expecting to have the hover jets equipped constantly but nope.
It's by far the most charming 3d Mario I've played but it's rough.
Just started Galaxy and it still has the Wii UI and you have to use motion controls just to select a save spot and start the game. changing my rating to 1 star, i hate this and am going to sell it as soon as i get tired of Sunshine
Edit*
64 doesn't get better than just jumping around the castle for me, the levels are just not very fun.
Got 83 stars in Sunshine and im not bothering with the last 2 red coin missions. It's a buggy, untested game with lots of charm but it generally kinda sucks outside of aesthetics. Every problem I listed annoyed me the entire playthrough. Also every single thing involving yoshi is bad. Feeding him, the unmovable egg, spawn location, dying in water, and i think he just explodes when his fruit meter runs out? i honestly dont get why they even put him in this game. its just redundant with fludd, he jumps slightly higher and sprays water... cool.
Galaxy is weird. collecting sparkles sucks and it has the worst camera of the bunch, touchscreen is bad, button prompts are big shaking joycons, and the beginning is kinda awful. but once i started crawling around on the giant bee it got a lot better. I might like this one, not sure yet

title: Switch Version
text:
Making this quick, or else I will go on a tantrum.
Nintendo Switch version BTW.
Rendering issues make the game frustrating most of the time and pretty much unplayable in survival.
The CONSTANT autosave feature slows EVERYTHING down and no way of turning it off on the Nintendo Switch. A boat ride is certain death.
Multiplayer, forget it, as their game saves you get stopped, vice versa.

I got my game the same day from Amazon and in perfect condition so delivery was great.

Update: after the latest update, the game freezes constantly, load times are completely unacceptable and for some reason, even logging into Microsoft takes forever.
Still no way to turn off autosave, so now with the added stuff, rendering issues have gone from frustrating to mind numbing.

title: List of Changes. Lazy Port. Collector's Only
text:
Basically a HD ports of Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine, and Super Mario Galaxy.

Also includes music player mode, which has entire original soundtracks of all three games. 175 tracks total. The music can be played when the screen is turned off in handheld mode. Only option is to play and stop. If you stop and start again it'll restart entire track as there's no progress bar.

HD upgrade. Graphics are slighly improved. Not a night-and-day difference, but noticeable.

Mario 64 runs at 720p with 4:3 aspect ratio which is disappointing

Both Sunshine and Galaxy is 1080p in TV Mode and 720p in Handheld Mode

Font and text are much clearer and easier to read

--List of changes in each game:

-Super Mario 64:

Camera controls are reversed

Jump audio is not as clear

No back jump exploit for speed runners

Mario no longer says "So long king bowser" when swinging and throwing bowser

-Super Mario Sunshine:

Does not support Gamecube controllers. Although there are GameCube controller icons on screen which is a bit odd.

HUD is smaller and doesn't fill up most of screen

Aiming up/down is no longer inverted

Only can shoot water at max power

Seeing Switch controls don't have analog triggers. ZR free shoot. R shoot in place.

-Super Mario Galaxy:

Can use joycons to collect star bits not not as responsive as Wii version/Wii remote controller. Curser has this odd drift at times. Also can use touch screen in handheld mode.

Press Y button to do spin attack instead of shaking controller (if you want)

Control camera via right stick instead of D-pad

---Misc info on all 3 games:

Able to change languages (7 languages total)

All games run at original frame rate

All games have rumble support (no HD rumble). Cannot be turned off

No gameplay or sensitivity options

No bonus or extra levels

No concept art/unlockables

--Closing thoughts:
Had fun playing games again. Aside from music mode, it's pretty much an uprezed version of original. If you have old versions of the game it's not really worth it unless you want all games in one location, lost previous copies, and/or have old consoles in storage and too lazy to find/set them up

Price is pretty steep at $20 per game for decades old games, and it's only available for limited time until March 2021.

I'd say it's only for collectors and hardcore fans of Mario games

title: Mario is always Mario
text:
I'll be honest, I bought this game solely for the purpose of replaying Super Mario Sunshine. I enjoyed the heck out of it on my GameCube, and it's still just as fun of the Switch.

I've already played Super Mario 64 on enough other devices that I'll skip this version.

Super Mario Galaxy I've never played, so I might try it out.

But Sunshine is the reason I bought this. And I am not disappointed at all. I can't wait until I get Mario up to level 40 so he can finally wear his Tier 1 Armor of the Undying so he can finally face the Zerg rush in Delfino Plaza. The Maserati you get as a reward is super-sweet!

title: Cheap Emulation
text:
There's nothing in this game you can get that you can't get better via emulation. Higher frame rate, save states, wide screen, version choice, choice of controller, and custom button mapping are just a few ways emulation is better than this low-effort cash grab made all the more insulting by this collection displaying clear hallmarks of emulation.

Previous collections on Nintendo consoles such as the the Megaman and Kirby collections (both originally $40) also have so much more for a far lower cost. Concept art, game commercials, trivia, in-game saving, cut scene skipping, new levels, and other additional content. None of which is here. The Kingdom Hearts collections included lost and region-locked content and were also only $40. The music player is nice, but it pales in comparison to the ability to save in a Megaman game right before a disappearing block section above instant-kill spikes.

Mario 64- Rumble is on by default and can't be turned off. It is also the patched version, so no backwards long jump or "So long'a bowser!" The Megaman ZX collection proved DS games can be played on the Switch seamlessly, but this isn't the DS port of Mario 64, or the port of this version on the Wii-U.

Mario Sunshine- Can't use gamecube controller on the gamecube game (these controllers work with Smash on Switch). The "Secret of the Dirty Lakes" mission has boundary boxes that only appear in the emulation process, so it is clear they emulated the game rather than remake it. They also messed with the controls. Aiming F.L.U.D.D. is inverted and can't be undone.

Mario Galaxy- The Nvidia Shield release allowed you to pick up star bits with the thumb stick... not this version!

If this was $20 I would not mind, but at a full priced game, Nintendo did not put in the effort for this to cost $60. This is nothing more than a cheap cash-grap. Shame on your Nintendo!

title: It's a-me, Barebones Mario!
text: My rating does not reflect the quality of the 3 games included. Each is a masterpiece and handles well. In terms of compilation quality, this is pretty poor. There are no options for the video. There is no ability to remap buttons. The menus are super basic and offer one special feature: soundtracks. There's no concept art, interviews, scans of the instruction manual, box art, basically anything other collections have done far better than this effort from Nintendo. If you go in expecting no bells and whistles, you shouldn't feel surprised by the lack of bonus content. Essentially, you'll learn more from YouTube videos delving into the history of these games than you will from the compilation itself.

title: Pretty much all you need, except for one thing.
text:
Literally the ONLY issue I have with this is the lack of Galaxy 2. It just feels weird to have Galaxy and not Galaxy 2.

The controls are responsive, each game looks great (best version you can get outside of custom fan patches) and it's a clean/simple interface pulling the three games together. I never played Sunshine and only played a few levels of Galaxy, so I am pretty happy to have this here. Would have also been nice for SM64 to be a remake based on the DS version (more content), but it's fine that it's basically just an HD port with some minor tweaks.

title: Quick cash grab
text:
So I played this the day before release, and found that on a 65" TV, it doesn't really look all that great. This is considering the age of the games. You could do better by emulating this yourself on Dolphin and injecting your own textures. It's truly a cheap port and barely an improvement.

The games as a whole are great. SM64 is as about as perfect as could be for a N64 Mario. Sunshine is actually the best, because it improved on 64 without straying too far from the linear fun of the Mario franchise. Galaxy would be more fun and better, if not for the gimmicky controls, and the repetitiveness of running around on tiny planets inappropriately called "galaxies". They are all worth the roughly $20, if you didn't get to play one or all of these, and don't want the trouble of emulating it yourself.

More on the physical aspect and Nintendo, the cartridge was actually ruined by the ESRB. Nintendo can't really control that, but you should know that the main logo is offset, and that will bother many people who overpay for this $60 piece of plastic. This game is supposed to be a "limited print", to celebrate Mario's 35 years, yet it is the sloppiest anniversary I've ever seen. It doesn't come with an actual sound track, no art, no steel book, cards, golden tickets, condoms, or even a simple thank you note. It's genuinely cheap through and through, and it's even more disappointing that the fact that there's still no new F-Zero, because at least they know not to do that if they can't do it right.

Overall, it's only worth it if it's $60 or less, and if you're a normie who isn't picky with the quality of the physical game. Although, if this would at all eat into your budget for a PS5 or any of it's cost, just save your money. You will get far more enjoyment out of Demon's Souls.

title: Terrible Collection
text:
I bought this for collecting reasons alone. As a game itself, I don't recommend it. But of course if you just want to simply buy it and keep it as a collectors item, understandable.

Cons
- Inconsistent FPS, SM64 is 30 FPS, SMS is 30 FPS, SMG is 60 FPS
- Inconsistent Aspect Ratio, SM64 is 4:3, SMS is 16:9, SMG is 16:9
- Lack of any major enhancements over originals
- Limiting the collection is annoying and done only to get people to buy for FOMO (Fear of missing out) reasons.
- Lack of any extra content surrounding the games like an art gallery, it just has a basic music collection which is basically useless.
- Feels like a cash grab and nothing more.

Pros
- You can play these treasured Mario games on the Switch
- That's it

title: Great, but...
text:
Three great Super Mario games at the price of $59.99, namely Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine, and Super Mario Galaxy. If you’re a fan of Mario, this is a MUST-HAVE.

With that said, the price for this collection feels a bit steep. Super Mario 3D All Stars includes the three games mentioned above, as well as the official soundtracks to each game inside the software.

One of my biggest disappointments with this is the seemingly lack of effort put into this collection for several reasons, including quality of life improvements and lack of extra content related to Mario’s 35th anniversary. At launch, the software felt rushed because of random glitches and slowdowns that weren’t even present in the original versions. These games are obviously running at a higher resolution than their original counterparts, so this should probably be expected- but these games are decades old now. Aside from emulation quirks that arise, you’d think that Nintendo would have put extra care and time into the development for this. I also think Nintendo could have done more things to improve upon the games, namely Mario Sunshine’s gameplay quirks- but I suppose that’s more forgiving if it involves changing source code.
There’s also not much content in terms of celebration. The soundtrack is all that is included, and it’s hard not to complain when past special editions included art books and physical soundtracks, or some kind of token- the last Mario anniversary release included these, albeit with a Super Nintendo game from the early ‘90s on a Wii disc, but it was priced ten dollars less.
It’s also inevitable to compare this collection to other similar software: Crash Bandicoot N. Same Trilogy and Spyro Remastered are two collections that completely REMAKE the original trilogies with new graphics, include extra content like development archives, and are priced at twenty dollars LESS than Super Mario 3D All-Stars. By no means should Nintendo have remade all three games, but the pricing of $59.99 left me confused and even felt cheated.

Overall, I would recommend this if you really want to play these games on your Switch. I don’t think it’s a bad deal by any means, but it leaves a desire for more.

title: Not worth $60
text:
This game is not worth the $60 it costs. This game was emulated by nintendo to fit to the switch and it had no updates to it. This means that the gameplay on the switch is just like it was on the N64, gamecube, or Wii. This is annoying in Mario 64, the first 3D game Nintendo came out with. They had not perfected the camera at that time and in 2020 the camera controls are still terrible.
There is also no more new content so you are paying $60 to Nintendo for work that they didn't really do.
You also cannot change the keys to any of the games, so in super mario sunshine i keep going to the map instead of doing a ground pound - super frustrating. and the controls are not inverted on the switch even though they were inverted on the GC and theres no way to reverse them.
Super Mario Sunshine is also an aesthetically pleasing game with a great premise and FLUDD was a delight to get as a sequel to Mario 64, but my gosh the game is repetitive and frustrating. I don't remember it being this bad as a kid.
I bought this game for nostalgia reasons but its honestly not worth $60.

title: 3 Solid Games in a Kinda Barebones Collection
text:
Likes:
+Being able to play Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine, and Super Mario Galaxy on the same system in HD. You could only do this on the Wii in standard definition, so this is definitely a step up.
+All 3 titles look really clear.
+Sunshine is now in 16:9, which REALLY helps with the game IMHO.
+I actually disliked Sunshine's original inverted controls, so I like the fact that the camera and aiming is not inverted. This is just a me thing though as others dislike the lack of inverted controls.
+Galaxy has the spin tied to the Y button.
+Kinda minor, but the initial load from the Switch menu to the game menu is VERY quick. This is likely because the majority of the loading is done after you choose one of the games within the collection.

Dislikes:
-Barebones UI for the menu.
-Lack of an Art Gallery and a Video Gallery that other collections like the Mega Man X Legacy Collection had. You just have the games and the soundtracks.
-Would've liked a remastered port or remake like what Crash and Spyro had instead of 3 emulations, but you get what you can get with Nintendo.
-I dislike the fact that this is a limited release as this will encourage scalpers to buy everything until there's no stock remaining and then sell it at a higher price.
-No more "So Long, King Bowser!" or backwards long jump glitch for speedrunning. Minor gripes, but still gripes.
-Weird editing for Fludd's explanation of how the controls work in Sunshine.

Overall, a solid collection, but it could be a bit better. I'd recommend grabbing it before scalpers do.

title: Great games, disappointing anniversary celebration...
text: Mario is 3 years my senior he's someone I've grown up with my whole life and to see his 35th birthday be celebrated in this way is a little disappointing. Why is super Mario All-Stars from super NES not on this I'll never understand, why is there not more music could they not have included the entire library of music from all the Mario games instead of just these games. This was the first video game I've ever pre-ordered due to the fact that it was going to be limited release and I didn't want to miss a copy of it because I do love Mario that much and I enjoy these games that much and I want a copy of them for my switch that I will always have and that I will never lose, but I feel like this was so underwhelming and the problem lies in the fact that Nintendo doesn't understand how important anniversaries are in the Western world maybe. A 35th anniversary deserves a real fanfare and while I'll probably get the pen set for pre-ordering this and doing everything else that just doesn't seem like enough to me and I would have paid for a premium packaging of this that included artwork or something. This was just a little bit too underwhelming for me and unfortunately I had no other choice but to buy it now or potentially pay a premium to have it in the future.

title: Avoid frustration Do Not Buy
text: DO NOT BUY!!! I bought this to be able to play with my daughter and at first it was great and we thoroughly enjoyed it.  But within a few weeks we started having issues with excessive log in times and then the storage issues oh the storage issues! It keeps giving an error message about not having enough storage space and I have plenty of storage only have 22 mb used so far.  The message reads "You are almost out of data storage space!  Minecraft has restricted access to this feature until you clear up additional storage space.  Excuse me?!  Clear up what?!  After backing up to the "cloud" and deletin the few games saved on my switch I am still getting this message.  And now this message is all you get no being able to access your worlds or playing the game at all!  Mojang's technical support is non existent so good luck getting any help.  After trying to research a solution, I finally found some vague reference to this being a bug in the game and update the game.  After updating the game which did not do a thing mind you then found another vague reference that everything being magically fixed with the current update which is a couple of months out.  So here we are i am now the proud owner of a useless and unusable game.  Save yourself the frustration and give the Switch Minecraft version a pass.

title: Nintendo is selling time machines!
text:
Pros: Updated graphics, added motion controls, all on one cartridge(no downloads).

Cons: No Mario Galaxy 2, no Luigi in M64(L is real).

Overall:
This is a great collectors item and excellent set of games. I am not really bothered by the fact this is a limited release, as Nintendo has done this many times before with other mario games and ended up re-releasing the same set of games just without a special cover.

I am really glad they kept the aspect ratio for M64 in 4:3 instead of widescreen, but cleaned up aliasing and texture quality.

Sunshine and Galaxy look a million times better and the motion controls in Galaxy are flawless.

title: The absolute best way to experience 3 classic Mario games
text: This is the best way to experience these games, period. The games have all been upscaled to HD resolution and they look amazing because of it. In my opinion Super Mario Galaxy benefits the most from this, it is an already beautiful game that is finally in full 1080p resolution. I should note every game here controls EFFORTLESSLY on Nintendo Switch. The controls for Super Mario 64 are especially impressive, considering how poorly the game ran on Wii and Wii U. Super Mario Sunshine gets a much needed widescreen addition, which really helps the game. And for those of you concerned with how Galaxy has been adapted, rest assured the game works great (if not even better) with the option to use traditional controls instead of motion controls. My only gripe with this collection is the lack of Super Mario Galaxy 2, which I  desperately hoping is added down the line as paid DLC. The collection lacks a lot of features used to flesh out other collections (such as a museum or a promotional material showcase), but I personally believe this collection is perfectly fine without it. You NEED this in your life if you are a Mario fan, period.

title: Charming, yet clunky.
text:
When this collection was first announced, I was pretty stoked. During my childhood, Mario kind of flew under my radar and I was more interested in Zelda and Pokemon, so I planned on this game hopefully giving me an introduction into some classic 3D Nintendo nostalgia. Let it be known that I bought this digitally.

Right away I could tell that they were all ports. Most, if not all the controls do not feel optimized for the Switch at all, especially Mario 64. I haven't played Sunshine yet, but Mario Galaxy has to be my favorite of the three. God, what a beautiful game that's slightly ruined by the fact that, yet again, the controls could use some work being adapted to the Switch. Motion is very bad, and collecting the stars still feels like it should be with the Wiimote.

Overall, I get what Nintendo was trying to do with this collection. But as far as the quality and worth goes, you're better off waiting for a sale. I just hope they don't completely botch a Zelda collection like they did with this one.

title: 3D-fic ! 👌
text:
When I 1st heard about rumors of a 3D Mario collection I was hoping it was true & glad it turned out to be true. Pros & Cons vary.

Pro.
3 classic 3D mario games. If you were to buy Mario 64 physical for the n64 it could cost you $30-$35 , Mario Sunshine could cost you an easy $50 & Mario Galaxy can easily cost you $30 so in total if you bought them individually it would cost you over $100. For just $60 you get all 3 games with full HD 800p to 1080p in dock mode & 720p mobile. You can tell the difference especially when you play mario galaxy which originally on the wii you were getting 420i & now to get 1080p is amazing. If you lied to me & said that it's a next gen mario game , I'd be fooled.
They throw in digital soundtracks for all 3 games & then you have the fact it can be played on the go.

Cons.
The bare bones job Nintendo did is shameful. This is supposed to be a 35th anniversary so where's the manual ? An art book ? A physical soundtrack ? Perhaps a mini figure ? Where's Mario Galaxy 2 ?

Final thoughts.
If you looking for a decent platformer compilation, you can always count on mario & super mario 3d all-stars is good enough to satisfy that itch. It's 3D-fic 👌

title: A fun building game... but only single-player works properly!
text:
I first tried this game on iPad. I was evaluating it to see if it would be good for my daughter to play. But I found it engaging myself and spent many hours playing around. It's a simple game where you gather resources and build things in a pixelated art-style 3D world. It's kind of like playing in a sandbox. There is no story, but kids love the creative freedom to explore, fend off monsters, and build all sorts of things.

I am reviewing the Nintendo Switch version here. I would rate it higher, but the online capability on the Switch is abysmal. Years ago, we tried networking a few devices to play over local connection (two iOS devices and a Switch). Even with that simple setup, we suffered frequent connection disruptions. By now, you would think that Microsoft would have improved things. The game now claims to offer online multiplayer on the Switch. But I found it to be utterly broken and non-functional. I have a solid internet setup at my house. But the game always fails to connect me with my Switch friends online. Signing in with a Microsoft account seemed to work better at first. But then it inexplicably started causing the game to lock up whenever I logged on with the Microsoft account.

It's a completely broken and frustrating experience trying to use the online features. If you stick to the single-player game, it's enjoyable as a simple little sandbox game. If Microsoft can't get the online experience right, they shouldn't claim that the game is playable online. They should wait until they have it working properly before releasing those features.

text:
When the rumors of this were circulating the interwebs I was all excited for it, but was confused when Nintendo announced it would be a *limited run* (because that worked so well for the NES/SNES Classic I guess). Also disappointed that these are pretty much a 1:1 emulation (*not* a port/remake) of each of the games, with very little extra features (A "digital soundtrack" mode; that's all)

Nothing wrong with the games themselves (Loved Mario 64 as a kid; never played Sunshine or Galaxy but gonna give it a go now), just confused on how Nintendo approached this.
(I will admit defeat to Nintendo though; as the F.O.M.O. with the limited production made me preorder this before hoarders start selling this for triple the price)

title: Just a lazy cash grab from Nintendo.
text: I have been a die hard Nintendo fan since at least age 7, and fondly remember playing these games when they originally came out. I was stoked by the rumors that there'd be a 3D Mario Collection, imagining everything it could have been. Instead, what we got was a lazy port of 3 games with only the bare minimum level of enhancement. I get that Nintendo was trying to go all preservationist as they do with their classic NES and SNES games, but the fact is, 3D games, especially early 3D games, just don't age as gracefully as the previous generations did. Take Super Mario 64, for instance. Much like Super Mario Bros., this was a genre-defining game and was mind-blowing at the time. The original Super Mario Bros. remains a near-perfect platformer to this day. But when Super Mario 64 came out, 3D platformers still had a lot to work out, and they have grown and evolved since then in almost every way, leaving this game in the dust. And as a result, it's almost unplayable today. No, I'm not going to repeat the classic complaints about it not being in widescreen or the graphics being blocky. I can see past those things, and to be honest I forget that it's even in 4:3 almost as soon as I start playing. I'm talking about things like having modern camera controls. This would have been one of the easiest things to implement, and it would have made the game SO much more enjoyable. Instead, I have to deal with endless frustration of missed jumps due to not being able to see Mario or his surroundings properly. As I said, in 1996 this game was amazing, but this isn't 1996, and I'm not playing it on an N64 with an N64 controller. In 2020 it comes off feeling broken and borderline unplayable. These three games, and Super Mario 64 in particular deserved better. The Mario franchise deserved better. And most of all, Nintendo fans deserved better. I'm just sad that so many people buy this game up and continue to rave about it. Just face the facts- Nintendo dropped the ball on this one, and unless people start to admit it, this won't be the last time.
