title: Some strange changes but overall, its Minecraft
text:
As others have stated before, to play with your friends away from each other online, you're gonna have to deal with Nintendos proprietary online surface which is lame. It is what it is.

When it comes to other things, for example the offhand slot in game, it is EXTREMELY limited in comparison to the PC version where you can offhand virtually any item in the game. With this version, you can only effectively use in the offhand maps, and shields. Shields in particular you use by "sneaking"/crouching.

Besides those things, it is by all means Minecraft, and relatively up to date to boot as this is the "Bedrock Edition".

One of the more impressive features is the ability to play fully locally with up to four players simultaneously EVEN IN TABLETOP mode!
There is a local wireless play as well. So if your friends have their Switch's with them, you can play with them even without the Nintendo online service. So if possible, to play effectively with others, try playing locally on one Switch, or attempt to play via local wireless with multiple Switch systems.

Yes Command Blocks are in this. So you can make those "in game mods" that are implemented solely by Command Blocks. That alone is a very powerful feature to be present.

As for any additional tips for this particular version I can give is, try going into the settings, go to the control rebind section(s), and bind "Jump" to "clicking" the Left stick. Then bind "Sneak" to the Right stick click. Those two bindings in combination helps a lot I've found.
Do note that as of 1/29/2020, there doesn't seem to be any way to disable "double tap forward to dash". So if you want to sprint, tap forward twice and you'll sprint. It would've been nice if it had a checkbox to disable that in case you wanted to bind sprinting to something else and not accidentally sprint from double tapping forward.

All in all, if you goal isn't the online multiplayer, or you used the offhand feature and love it to death on PC, you're better off staying on PC/Windows-10-Version. If you can live with those compromises, or your party of friends like to play locally to begin with, its a great time! Its definitely a lot more manageable to make those large buildings by chipping away at your tasks a little bit at a time. Which is really easy to do due to the nature of the Switch.

Do note that in order to play with others locally on one Switch system, you'll need to give your friends some sort of controller that has two joy sticks. You could hypothetically use a gamecube adapter in docked mode, and let your friends play with you via Gamecube controller. So no, you cannot play with one Joy Con per player in this game. But considering it uses twin stick controls, that is to be expected.

title: So worth it!!!
text:
The first time I played Mario 64 I was 10 years old. It was one of the first console games I had ever played. Over the years, I have tried emulators and the DS game that was released but neither of those came close to the original expectations I had when playing this game. This did. I’m so happy I purchased it. Getting to replay the same levels from my childhood and making the same mistakes, but also playing better and getting stars that used to be impossible for me to get is pretty cool. Kind of like having a conversation with your younger self. Playing this game in this format was very fulfilling for me. That said, the camera is a bit difficult to deal with. The format isn’t a problem at all. Minor things for me.

Another reason for buying this game is... I grew up poor, I never got a Gamecube or a Wii so I never got the chance to play Sunshine or Galaxy. I jumped at the chance to get all 3 games for 20 bucks each basically.

I’ve been wishing for something like this to happen ever since I got a switch. 10 year old me cried when I was able to play Mario 64 in a handheld comfortably the DS version was such a letdown.

title: If you enjoy these games or LOVE Mario, than this is great.
text:
All three games are good/great. I grew up playing Sunshine and Galaxy and 64 is a classic. Its easy to switch between games. I recommend playing with the pro controller on the big screen as much as possible. I personally think 64 has a difficulty curve with the controls and fighting the camera. Sunshine got the biggest graphical overhaul. galaxy has the biggest change in controls(uses the gyro in the controller for aiming the cursor or touch if playing in handheld). the music is great, especially in galaxy. Galaxy is the easiest of the games. I had a harder time playing 64 but sunshine has some difficult challenging levels (a pachinko machine and a lily pad level come to mind.)

I personally think 64 is a bit over hyped and dated but good. Sunshine is great for the most part. Galaxy is as good as it has ever been. (note: yes I know you can emulate the games on the computer but legally its questionable to do it that way but this is an honest way to play these games, especially on the go!!) If you don't own these games, and want a nostalgia trip, this will do it. but don't wait too long if you want it, cause it will be gone after march?

title: Only Galaxy is enjoyable
text:
Super Mario 64: Experience is very very bad honestly. Low refresh rate make you feel like the game is stucky *all the time*. Locked angle makes barely playable.

Galaxy: buttery smooth and a great game!

Sunshine: perhaps in the middle. Playable, but hardly a good experience either.

To be fair, I am not sure what Nintendo could do to improve 64 since many limitations cannot really simply resolved in a remake. However, this is not a cheap collections as well. So I would say your expectation should be paying $60 dollars on a Galaxy switch remake. If you want it, great! Otherwise, this is not a good buy for sure.

title: A lazy compilation
text:
I bought this mainly because I wanted to replay Super Mario 64.

Playing Super Mario 64 for the first time in 1996 is one of my best videogame memories. The game was absolutely stunning at that time, no other 3d platformer was nearly as good.
25 years later... I'm glad to re-play this but certain aspects of the game really didn't age well.

The biggest flaw is the camera. Wow, does the camera stink in this game! It was really innovating to be able to control the camera back in the days that you'd look past it's flaws, but by today's standards it's just very messy and not ok. It just sometimes refuse to move or stay where you want to stay in areas where precision is required. Not a deal breaker but it's certainly frustrating.

Overall Mario 64 still has magical moments, it's certainly a classic and I mostly enjoyed playing through it, some parts of the game and certain textures are actually surprisingly pretty, like inside the pyramid (and has very little to do with the resolution increase in the port). And the music is still awesome.
But Nintendo really should have at least fixed the camera and some of the uglier textures if they didn't want to do bother with a (well deserved) remake to this masterpiece.

Coming up with a follow up to Mario 64 that wouldn't disappoint fans was a very hard endeavor even if Nintendo tried hard, and I don't think they really did it with Mario Sunshine. Wasn't a favorite when it was originally released on the Gamecube and I still dont care much for it. Unlike 64, the game's graphics aged surprisingly well though.

Mario Galaxy is the best of the bunch, the spiritual successor to Super Mario 64. I played this so much on the Wii that I still don't feel ready to fully replay this game, but if you didnt play any of those games before it's for sure the best. The formula was improved even more on Mario Galaxy II - why the heck isn't it included here??

Overall it's hard to review this. It's a collection of very lazy ports of fantastic games. No interesting extras just the soundtrack.
Super Mario 64 especially should really have been cleaned up (poor camera, some ugly textures)
I recommend this if you are really craving some nostalgia time with any of the games in the collection. Otherwise, Nindendo did little to make them appealing to today's standards.
Try harder, Nintendo.

I added an extra star from my original review as two stars was a bit harsh considering the high quality source material. But the point remains, I wish Nintendo had tried harder.

title: Classic's ....... nuff said
text:
Best versions since the originals and I would say better in some cases. If your a collector or grew up with these games this is a must own. If you played other mario games but not these, give em a shot .... they are timeless.

Mario 64 - yah it 4:3..... so was the original. Its been cleaned up and upscaled to 720p. Could they have done better.... maybe but its still an amazing game. Slow down present in the Wii-U version is none existent so this make the best version you can buy.
Mario Sunshine - Never looked better. Upgraded to full HD widescreen it looks great and probably the most straight forward to play. While some didn't like the original I still think its a gem and well worth the time.
Mario Galaxy - The most recent also the best looking. Controls are a bit wonky but the mind bending puzzles are unlike anything you see in other Mario games.

In summery.... if your a collector or plan to play it mobile buy the cartridge. If not buy the download .... but don't wait too long as 1st party Nintendo titles don't depreciate in price like other systems or games. And once its out of print its not getting any cheaper.

title: It’s a little hard, but I like the customizations
text: I bought this for my seven-year-old boy, because it seems like every boy likes Minecraft. But honestly, I ended up having to play to figure out the controls and settings before he could really play. And he’s usually very good at difficult games, like Zelda and Eldin Ring. It’s just really confusing. There’s really no tutorial, unless I somehow missed it? I don’t know. Then we had to Google how to find the house he made, because you don’t start where you were- you start on a random part of the map and have to find your buildings. It’s just a difficult game. He played it for a few days and got bored and hasn’t played it since, and I’m not really a fan either. Maybe it’s just us, I don’t know. Just make sure, if you’re buying this for a child, you play it first and figure out the controls and settings because it’s hard to figure out. Also make sure to tell them to screenshot or write down the longitude and latitude of their creations, or they’ll spend over an hour trying to find it like we did. I’m just not impressed. With how popular this game is, I expected it to be really fun and foster creativity for my kid, but it was just confusing and frustrating… and we’re both very into a wide variety of video games and it was hard for us.

title: The best way to play 3 amazing classics
text: This is the best way to play all of these classic games! I loved them as a child, and playing them on the switch truly improves the visuals, making it look how you thought it did as kid. You can’t beat the price for all 3 games in one, and they’re all absolutely amazing! The controls are great, but I do recommend using the pro controller for it! The game will stop being produced after March 2021, and will be taken off the Nintendo E shop at that time as well, so I do recommend picking up a physical or digital copy while you can! You won’t regret it, and it will leave you entertained for many, many hours! :)

title: An extremely buggy and poorly optimized port to the Nintendo Switch.
text: An extremely poor port. This new version is buggy, lags, and has poor frame rate and huge rendering drops, compared to the traditional console edition. Inventory gets deleted, game crashes, multiplayer chugs. It's a very, very poor port. My advice is to buy the Nintendo Switch Edition of Minecraft on the Eshop, and wait for this port to be fixed (if it ever does [Xbox players have been complaining about this port since it launched back in 2017]). You can buy the eShop version and get a free upgrade to the new "Minecraft" edition, that this is. Your old worlds can even be converted over. Though, like I said, this port is extremely buggy and difficult to deal with. Wait till they fix the bugs, then it might be worth it.

title: Outstanding value
text:
For those complaining about the bare-bones re-releases, keep in mind that if these were given the full remake (i.e. Link's Awakening) the 3 games would be $60 each, and we'd be talking about a $180 package.

But given the $60 price point, the value is spot on for basic ports. The games are fun, they've never looked better, and at $20 a piece it's a great value.

Maybe someday you'll get your wish for a full-fledged remake, but be prepared to pay up when that happens.

text: The bundle is definitely worth it for its price, and I think that people fail to realize that this bundle was never a remake to begin with. You are purchasing a port, and the trailer was pretty straight to the point that it was going to be a port of the old games. Don't go into this and expect that it is going to be top notch quality when that was never Nintendo's intentions in the first place. Other than that, I am pretty satisfied for what it is. The tweaks and minor updates are definitely there but not noticeable, so it still has the same feel of the originals.

title: Classic collection but perhaps only for old fans
text:
A simple emulation/port of three older 3D Mario games. I'm not a Mario fanboy, and I never played these growing up so I was excited and curious to try them for the first time. I knew they were ports or emulations or whatever, but even a few QoL changes would have been welcome.

Unfortunately, the classic M64 just doesn't hold up for a first-timer and Mario is so fiddly and twitchy plus poor camera control makes it hard to appreciate it for what I am sure it once was. Mario Sunshine looks nice but suffers from some strange mechanics and I frankly didn't play it much and would even argue M64 is a better experience. Galaxy is probably my favorite as it appears this is when Nintendo finally polished up the 3D experience and will probably be the only one I'll finish.

In hindsight, I somewhat regret spending $60 on this, but fans of the originals should enjoy this. 5/5 for classic reasons, but 2/5 for modern enjoyment. Maybe I just don't have patience for fussy platformers anymore and I kept thinking I'd rather be playing something else more refined. Hard to recommend when there are so many other great games out now worth $60 or less. Finally, it really offers nothing for people who are new to the old series to generate any enthusiasm or interest so it is basically a nostalgia cash-in.

title: Incredibly Slow
text:
The game takes over 10 minutes to load with one of our accounts. And it often reports that there is not enough disk space, even though the console has 18GB free. I read somewhere that the game only recognizes 2GB max of saved game content. This is bizarre and needs to be fixed. It also means you cannot purchase any add-one from the store when Minecraft thinks the disk is full.

What’s strange is that the load speed is fine with other accounts. Seems that when you have too many worlds in a particular account it becomes incredibly slow, to the point of being unusable.

This has persisted for months, even though the latest update claims to have fixed any loading speed issues. We bought 3 copies of the game for 3 Switches. The problem happens only with one user account. But it’s unacceptably slow.

title: Timeless classics in an overpriced, lazy collection.
text:
Please note that my rating is not based on the individual games in this collection, which are all classics, each deserving 5 stars. I rated this collection a bit lower because I feel that Nintendo put minimal effort into this, and charged a premium price. Very greedy of Nintendo in my opinion.

For $60, this collection should have included Galaxy 2. No matter how you spin it, Nintendo is being greedy and or lazy by not including Galaxy 2. Mario 64 should have had a widescreen toggle. Both Mario 64 and Sunshine should be running at 60 frames per second, rather than 30 frames per second.

Would I purchase this collection again? Yes, however I feel a $40 price tag would have been more appropriate, due to the reasons I have listed. If you don't care about the things I mentioned, then you should buy this collection.

title: Worth it for Sunshine
text: While I’d always heard mostly negative things about Mario Sunshine, this game is amazing.  While I’ve mostly heard wonderful and amazing things about Galaxy, it’s mostly underwhelming. Sunshine is the opposite with its large environments, cohesive interesting world (the most fun Mario world for sure).  Mario 64 speaks for itself and looks and plays beautifully with the Pro Controller. Sunshine>64>Galaxy.

title: Low-Effort Money Grab
text:
I played Super Mario 64 extensively on the Nintendo 64 in my younger years. I was excited about the ability to play it on the Switch.

PROS
For the first time in history, Super Mario Sunshine and Super Mario Galaxy are available on-the-go. The graphics of Super Mario Galaxy look fantastic in HD. The motion controls of Super Mario Galaxy worked well in both tabletop mode and docked mode, despite the Switch not having a sensor bar like the Wii. Some people have stated that the lack of a sensor bar ruins the motion controls in Super Mario Galaxy, but I had no problems with them.

CONS
I was expecting Nintendo to provide some enhancements to each game in this collection, much like how the original Super Mario All-Stars consisted of enhanced remakes of the original NES games. I knew that Nintendo was probably not going to completely remake these games from scratch, but I was hoping that Nintendo would at least improve the controls and the user interface.

Instead, this collection consists of glorified emulation. I found myself constantly fighting the camera controls in both Super Mario 64 and Super Mario Galaxy. Super Mario 64 is not even rendered with a 16:9 aspect ratio, so it looks even more dated.

SUMMARY
If I wanted to play Super Mario 64 just as it appeared in 1996, I would have simply powered-up my Wii U and played the Virtual Console version of it. If I wanted to play Super Mario Galaxy just as it appeared in 2007, I would have simply powered-up my Wii U, booted into Wii mode, and then inserted my Super Mario Galaxy disc. I expected this release to offer something new, and I was very disappointed.

Perhaps I should have waited until watching gameplay footage before dropping $60 on this game. However, I pre-ordered this game because I feared that, due to the COVID-19 pandemic and the limited release window, this title would be difficult to buy later-on. Essentially, I got played by Nintendo's low-effort money grab.

title: Someone told you to get this game otherwise you wouldn't be reading reviews.
text:
Is it okay for kids?
- Yes, 6 and up but under 8 may need help or guidance.

Is it scary?
- Yes & No, there are creatures who will creep up on you and explode. They are the green pixilated rectangles called Creepers. Surprise is the extent of the scare.

What does open world and/or sandbox mean?
- Open world: means that the game creates a unique landscape that somebody can explore in a way that feels endless.
- Sandbox: this means that the player gets to create, design, construct, at their leisure. It's more exploratory than it is adventure.

Hope that helps somebody out there.

I've been playing Super Mario Sunshine and I cannot get through more than 30 minutes at a time without the game either crashing, glitching, or a bug revealing itself.

I fell through the 'floor' of the game and died randomly. I beat the flower boss only to have it restart the battle from the beginning. The game crashed three times so far. A tree is small, yet I can climb it up to 4-5 times its height (I'm climbing air). Another boss glitching every time I spray with water so that I cannot land a blow - took me 15 minutes to beat him because of this glitch when it should have been 2 or 3 minutes.

I loved these games on their original platforms. This re-release should have been postponed until it was tested more. This is unacceptable. Shame on you Nintendo.

title: Have always enjoyed Minecraft
text:
I have been playing Minecraft since the early years of the Java Edition. I spent many hours playing the Java Edition, and tried the Pocket Edition, but missed many of the omitted features. After purchasing my Nintendo Switch I opted to purchase the Switch Edition even though it was only available digitally (I prefer physical copies of the games I buy). I spent nearly 500 hours on the Switch Edition before the Bedrock edition finally released for the Switch.

I was hesitant to purchase the Bedrock edition as I had played it on my Samsung Galaxy Tab S 10.5" and it was quite glitchy and the graphics were different enough to catch my attention. I am glad that I purchased it because the issues I have on my Galaxy Tab S were, apparently, due to the limitations of the tablet's hardware. The Bedrock edition for my Switch has been running smoothly, although the map generation is different than the Switch edition which is a bit of a bummer.

Overall, I quite enjoy the Bedrock edition and having the ability to play with friends on Xbox One, Windows 10, Android, and Apple systems is a great bonus.

title: If you’ve never played these games, go get it, otherwise skip it
text:
There isn’t a single main Mario game that isn’t an instant hit. And these are arguably the three best Mario games. So if you haven’t played them or you are really nostalgic about them this is a great opportunity. The reason I give it two stars is that this is an emulation, not a complete port. The first Mario All Stars for the SNES gave us remade versions of classic games with updated graphics and textures. This time they decided to just upscale the graphics a little, add the word “limited release”, and charged us full price for decades old games. And btw, this is the third tome we get Mario 64, the first remake for the DS offered new content and new textures which for some reason are not available here.

Bottomline, excellent games but low effort in modernizing them making it a bit overpriced

title: Honestly, I think everyone is a little spoiled...
text: I felt inclined to write a review due to the amount of negativity I was reading on this product. This product was not supposed to “fix” the original games. It was intended to give us the ability to play games that are essentially lost, on a console that everyone now has at their disposal. I myself still have my N64, but I doubt the majority of the population does. As for “fixing” camera ability or “remastering the quality” why would you? People buy arcade machines to play games older than myself. Why? Because you play a game in its original aesthetic and appreciate it as is. There are games that were never ported, and once I lost them, I will never be able to play them again. We have a plethora of new, flashy, trendy games coming out in spades every year. Why do we need to change what came before? This is meant for people to reclaim a moment of their gaming childhood. Stop complaining and be happy that Nintendo took the time to give us back something we lost.

title: Only For Diehard Mario Fans
text:
As a huge fan of Nintendo and Mario games, I was really looking forward to this collection. I had previously played all three of these titles on their original consoles, so I was curious to see how they upgraded the camera and controls. I soon discovered the answer: they didn't. All three games are straight ports of the originals with a resolution upgrade and little else. They did add a music player so you can listen to the music from all three games, and while that's kind of cool, in practice who actually uses this feature?

The resolution on Super Mario 64 is sharper but the textures are still from 1996 which results in some sharp UGLY textures. And man is the camera ever horrible. I can understand that this was Mario's first 3D adventure, so I forgave the original for having a camera that's difficult to control and at times unresponsive. But in a collection such as this, I think it's pure laziness on Nintendo's part that the camera controls were not at least modernized to eliminate some of the original's issues. It is mapped to the R stick but the responsiveness is the same as when it was mapped to the N64's "C" buttons. It will swing wildly behind Mario at inopportune times and obscure what's in front of you. It's hard to position to see far enough out during the platform sections, so you often will miss a jump. And when you do try to reign it in, it will often get stuck on the landscape and not move at all. Mario himself still controls like his clunky '96 self, so he tends to slide quite a bit when trying to stop and making precise movements with him over a narrow platform is often a lesson in patience.

Super Mario Sunshine benefits more from the resolution bump and looks beautiful in the new expanded aspect ratio. It appears they did not upgrade the in game movie parts however and it's pretty obvious from their blurry appearance. This is a bit of nit picking however. Unfortunately, the game again suffers from lazy control ports. While the F.L.U.D.D. was easy to control with the original Gamecube controller, the button mapping is now awkward and has a steep learning curve before you truly feel even a little bit comfortable with it. One button lets you fire in place and control the up and down with the L controller. Another button lets you fire and strafe, and yet another lets you fire straight ahead while running. I often times was completely frustrated by the lack of control I had over the stream in boss fights and during platforming sections (Hotel Lobby...!!) and can't help to think there could have a been a better option for the controls. It's hard to remember what button does what and often results in moving Mario when I meant to leave him in place or vice versa in the heat of the moment. The camera is the same as the original, and while it's a marked improvement over Mario 64's, it still is a product of it's time and is often difficult to line it up precisely in the platforming sections or while using the hover attachment. So be prepared to fall often.

Super Mario Galaxy suffers the least in this collection and what is already one of Mario's most gorgeous looking adventures is even better looking with the resolution upgrade. There are motion controls in the game, which I'm not sure could be changed given the original Wii's remote, but they are implemented about as well as you can expect. The camera in this one won't give you many issues, because it's excellent compared to the previous two games. It moves with the action and is always about where you need it to be. Corrections that are needed are usually only small adjustments one way or the other. And while all three games have a great soundtrack, this one really shines and is one of my favorites of all Mario games.

There is a certain nostalgia factor that is included with these games for people such as myself, so regardless of the lazy collection, I will still play it. And that's what Nintendo seems to bank on. While the original Super Mario All Stars featured upgraded graphics and small control tweaks, Nintendo seems to think this is no longer necessary even though one only needs to look to the internet to know how good Mario 64 could look given a little extra TLC. Also, the absence of Galaxy 2 is puzzling and a little disappointing. If these Mario collections are supposed to truly be "a collection", then why leave parts out? I fully suspect they are planning a re-release like they are doing with Super Mario 3D World in order to milk a little more money out of diehards like myself.

So for those that have fond memories and an affinity for all things Mario, you're probably going to buy this anyway. But for those looking to experience these games for the first time, I'm not sure this is the right experience. You would be better off playing them on their original consoles so you can use the original control scheme mapped to each consoles unique controllers. It's kind of a shame really.

title: Great Games, Not Much Else
text:
If you are getting this game with the expectation that you will get a massive graphic overall, a la Mario All Stars (SNES), you will be disappointed. These games look and feel pretty identical to their original N64, Gamecube, and Wii releases.

That being said, I still think these games are pretty fun. Mario64 is definitely showing its age, but nostalgia goes a long way towards easing any misgivings I had about it. I think Sunshine is a lot of fun. I don't understand what some people dislike about it. Galaxy is as great as ever.

The only "extra" in the game is the ability to play the soundtracks from all three games. This meant almost nothing to me, but it might be of interest to you. It would be great if they had made some quality of life improvements (especially to the camera in Mario64), but all of the games are still very playable and fun.

title: I'm happy I picked it up, but I hope these glitches get fixed
text:
The framerate seems pretty solid to me. The Mario theme is a bit gimmicky and doesn't appeal to me, and the music gets old. The simulation distance is capped at 8 chunks which would have been nice to be able to increase. Battery life seems good, 3 hours took me to about 55% from a full charge. Local multiplayer was not laggy at all. Overall a great portable version of minecraft, but after about 30 hours of gameplay, I've seen a few glitches (even after a software update) that I hope will be fixed:

1. The menu cursor gets in a loop where it'll keep moving in a certain direction. This is not a problem with my controller since it doesn't affect me outside of the menu, or on the Switch home screen. I've had this happen twice.
2. Transparent blocks. I ran around a hill and the ground was transparent, seems like the world didn't load properly. This seems to not be specific to the Switch version. Happened to me once.
3. It will occasionally prevent me from crafting the last of an item. For example, if I have enough materials to make 3 axes, I can make the first 2, but the third will be impossible to make, even though it appears in the menu as craftable. I click and it just does nothing. I've had this happen 3 times.
4. I had the game completely freeze on me while I was sailing around picking sugarcane. Only happened once.

Other than the freezing, all of these glitches were fixed by saving and quitting. For what it's worth, I've spoken with others who haven't experienced any glitches, so... who knows.

title: Mario The Great
text:
Mario has always been my inspiration since childhood. Though I'm working on my Mario collection, for the third time, I figured I'd add this to my arsenal. I already have Super Mario 64 downloaded on my Wii U, yet I will be playing through it once more on Super Mario 3D All-Stars. This game will save people much money if they were looking to get the classic Super Mario Sunshine on the Nintendo Gamecube, as that's the only classic that isn't downloadable.

Overall, I loved this game. Long live Mario The Great!

Edit: My only complains are that they should have added more content to all three titles, as well as a repeat option for the soundtracks. Moreover, they could have also included unreleased soundtracks. Anything to commemorate Mario's 35th anniversary than what we got. Super Mario 3D All-Stars is great, yet could have been much better.

title: Great old games, not the best way to play them.
text:
All three of these Mario games are great, and just like you remember them. The resolutions have been improved, and in some instances the textures and graphics -- albeit very slightly. The deal-breaker is that there was an opportunity to modernize these games to make them a better experience, and instead the camera in Mario 64, and the controls in all three games are subpar, even compared to their original controllers. You will be frustrated.

It's also a bummer that Mario 64 still has fixed camera angles and a 4:3 aspect ratio. There is no excuse, as there are other versions available that implement these features.

If you're looking for a nostalgia trip, or just want to play that one Mario game you missed, you may think you have a good excuse to get this. For me, I never experienced Sunshine. However, be warned that you will be frustrated at Nintendo, and that this could have been a very special collection that instead feels like someone just charged you 60 dollars to play a bad port of an old rom.

It's tacky and disgusting. My 5 year old ended up spending some leftover credit from a giftcard without understanding what he was doing, and I'm sure the publishers are counting on that. Absolutely reprehensible business practice. When your game has sold more copies than any game in existence I think you can afford to not use microtransactions or at least make them restricted by age. But no, there's no way to hide the online marketplace in a super popular children's game.

title: Not the best collection
text:
Super Mario is fun in 2D, 3D, and VR. No matter what game it is, there's some fun to be had. These three games in particular are great, but the collection is very flawed.
It's lacking in content, (just three games and their sound tracks) none of the controls have been majorly updated and it shows the worst in Mario 64 (I never liked how Galaxy controlled in the first place). The most baffling omission however, is that this anniversary collection does not include Galaxy 2 at all! Just three games, with no major updates or additions. To make it worse, this won't be sold after March.
If you have to have these games on your Switch, fine. If you want 3D Mario? Just get Odyssey, it's the best this series has ever been and it's not a limited release.

title: HD Upscale ports of three of the best games of all time
text:
I'm going to keep this short and sweet: these are the same games that you played on the N64, Gamecube, and Wii. They are presented in HD with some minor graphical and control tweaks, but overall they're still the same games. Mario 64 is 720p with 4:3 aspect ratio. Sunshine is 1080p and widescreen now, with R and ZR used in place of the Gamecube's pressure-sensitive shoulder button. Galaxy has touchscreen controls for when playing handheld.

The release is pretty barebones compared to other similar collections, only offering minor improvements and the soundtracks, but the games are still among the best of all time, which is definitely the most important part.

title: Great. Nintendo could've done better
text: I have never played the originals. So when I picked up this version, this was going to be the first time I have played any of the 3 games. I have not played galaxy yet (nor have I played galaxy 2 for that matter) and will update this when I do. Played sunshine first. Didnt have much issues and beat the game. What I really had a problem with were the platform levels. The platform levels felt harder than they should and probably will be the only reason I wont collect all the stars. I played mario 64 next and I have not beaten it yet. Right now I'm at 102 stars. Keep in mind that all 3 of these games at literally ports. They're not remastered or remakes. They're the same copies as the original besides different controls. Think the only drastic thing they changed were the frame rates. So when I say the camera still sucksz it really still sucks. You can jump onto a platform above you and the camera will still be stuck underneath and it is a STRUGGLE to fix it so you can see where you are going. You also dont have much room to look around with the camera. The controls are also not that good. If you press down on the left analog stick too much while mario is looking foward, mario will still walk in that direction. I have accidently walked off cliffs because of this. In mario 64, It felt like they couldve done more with a 25 year old game and it just feels like they didnt really touch it much. With sunshine, it feels like they didnt play through the whole game to test it. The games are the same mario games you all know and love otherwise. Just wish nintendo did better

title: Nostalgia can only take me so far.
text:
Theee great games from the past. But like many, they are better in memory than in actuality.

Now, don’t get me wrong. They are still greet games. But they definitely feel dated. It doesn’t help that Nintendo did very little to rethink the controllers, to upgrade the graphics and to polish anything at all.

This is especially true with Mario 64. As awesome as that game is, it could’ve benefited from a graphics boost and controller tweaks.

Also, these are E-rates games that are not as accessible as I thought. My 7-year old is having a hard time getting into the games. So much so, that he actually jumped ship and is now playing the original Ratchet and Clank rereleased games on my PS3 and enjoying them a lot more. He already got through the original Ratchet and Clank and is now on Going Comando. He’s shown little interest to go back to any of these games and tells me that he’s just doesn’t like how the Mario games feel. Heck, he’s also playing with Luigi’s Mansion 3 and enjoying that one as much as R&C Going Comando.

title: It's a collection of 3-D Mario Games!
text:
It's the first 3 3-D Mario games in one collection! What's not to love?

Well, a few things. First, the games have only been lightly touched up graphically; Nintendo could have done a lot more to make the games look better on the Switch (this is really apparent on Mario 64, that does not play in full screen). Given that Nintendo has released past games in HD, it feels like they dropped the ball on this collection. Second, the Switch controls weren't adapted too well for these games. Mario 64 and Mario Sunshine feel "slippery"; the controls are too sensitive for these games, and you will get frustrated when a simple action (like walking/running in a straight line) is impossible. For Mario Galaxy, the game uses the touch screen when played in hand held which is... interesting (I kinda liked it, but I can see how others will find it disappointing). When played on the TV, the Joy-Cons have use the motion control and pointing that the Wii used but with one MAJOR difference: They are not optically aiming at the screen, but rather "mimicking" such action, meaning that they don't point exactly where you intend them to. This is exasperated when using a Pro-Controller. The motion control parts of the game (like Ray Surfing or riding the Star Ball) also control weirdly. I honestly wish they would have re-done the control schemes for these so that you didn't have to rely on the motion controls alone.

The last thing about this collection is Nintendo's announcement of when it will be discontinued. I can see them making a limited production run for the physical copies, but there is no reason to remove the game from E-Store other than creating artificial scarcity.

Despite all this, I would still recommend the collection. It is probably the best way to get these games legally for the foreseeable. If you don't have the original hardware or don't want to buy expensive copies on the used market, then this is the best solution. All three games in the collection are fantastic (even with all the flaws I mentioned above). If you're new to these games, or picking them up for nostalgic reasons, then this collection is for you.

title: Controls Are Cancerous
text:
I have not played Mario 64 of Mario Galaxy, but I imagine the controls are just as bad if not worse than Super Mario Sunshine. Here is the breakdown of issues.
- A button is A button, ok that's fine
- B button is also A button, what?
- Y button is B button, I guess I can try to live with that, but why isn't it close up mode?
- Right stick is close up mode instead of Y button, may I ask why?
- X button is still X button, thank god
- When you enter close up mode the controls are inverted so you look up for up and down for down instead of up for down and down for up on GameCube version
- There is no option to remap the buttons so you are stuck with this mess until then
I kept getting frustrated throughout the beginning of the game trying to "re-learn" the new controls. Unless they allow us to change the controls and remap the buttons this will remain 1 star.

title: Poorly emulated cash-grab
text:
First off, the marketing tactic of making this a "limited time release" did not sit well with me. I'm actually fine with Nintendo repackaging these classics as a cash grab, but using false scarcity to drive up demand is shady.

However, my kids are obsessed with Mario (Odyssey and Deluxe) and I thought I would swallow my objections so they could experience Mario from my youth (Mario 64). I wasn't too bothered with the fact that they hadn't remastered anything, I figured that would ensure smooth performance...I was wrong.

The first thing I noticed when excitedly powering on Mario 64 for the first time in 20 years (aside from the incredible delta between the graphics I remember in my head vs what was pictured on my screen) was the lag. If I'm trying to emulate a game on my Rasberry Pi, that kind of lag is frustrating, but understandable. If I'm playing a 25 year old game I paid $60 for on a $300 console, then that is just inexcusable. Mario Sunshine was also painfully laggy, and Galaxy was OK.

How did Nintendo not put any money towards optimizing the performance? How is a $300 "modern" console with four 1GHz CPUs outperformed by a 25 year old console a single 100MHz CPU. I understand the emulation overhead, but with what they are charging for this, they should have ported the source code instead of emulating.

I feel bad for rewarding Nintendo with this purchase. I returned it after our poor experience, but Amazon only gave me a partial refund.

title: A must-have for older Mario fans, and maybe even newer ones
text:
If you're a fan of Mario's older 3D platforming titles, then you simply MUST do yourself a favor and pick a copy of this game. And if you're younger, I'd still recommend to seriously consider picking up a copy - to better appreciate how far Mario has come in his epic 3D adventures, and simply because some of his older stuff remains a blast to play to this day.

Three classic games in one is tough to beat. And even years later, I think all three titles are a blast to play.

Nintendo enhanced the look of all three titles, so the graphics look a little nicer. And I find that gameplay for all three games transitions pretty well on the Switch console.

Super Mario 64 and Super Mario Sunshine play pretty well for me on the Switch Pro Controller. And for the most part, I find Super Mario Galaxy works well with the detached joycons. The motion controls can take a little getting used to, but I find after a little while it begins to feel natural.

I would say Super Mario 64 hasn't aged perfectly well. The 1996-era graphics, awful camera and at times finicky controls can be frustrating. But this is still a very fun game - I'm also a sucker for nostalgia.

I have never played Super Mario Sunshine prior to it being in released on 3D All-Stars, and I must say that it is both terrific and frustrating at the same time. The game has aged well graphically, and the environments, movements and levels are a bunch of fun. Be warned though, if you're a casual game like me, this game can immensely frustrating at times. Some levels are brutal in difficulty (IMO), but persevering through the tougher ones does feel incredibly rewarding. I'm so glad I played this game.

I had a lot of fun on Super Mario Galaxy back in the late 2000s, and the game still looks and plays fantastic to this day. The graphics are still quite pleasing, the levels are highly intriguing, and the overall gameplay is so much fun. This is one of Mario's best adventures for sure. The difficulty is balanced well. Some levels can be pretty tricky, and a few can be considered downright difficult, but you don't have to be amazing to beat this game. This may be the best title among the the trio of games on 3D All-Stars.

Overall, I've had a blast re-exploring two classic Mario titles, while discovering the world of Super Mario Sunshine for the very first time. Getting three awesome titles for $60 bucks is a great deal - and if you aim to beat each one 100%, the hours you can sink in will definitely give you your money's worth. Plus, each title has pretty darn good replay value.

So please, if you're a fan of Nintendo's iconic Italian plumber - whether hard core or simply casually - do yourself a favor and buy 3D All-Stars. I don't think you'll regret it at all.

title: The only reason you bought this is because Nintendo’s limited release.
text:
This game set is bland as hell, and not worth 60 dollars.

I can play an hd remake of Mario 64 on pc for absolutely free, I can play Mario Sunshine on GameCube and add hdmi for a better experience overall, and the fact that Mario Galaxy 2 isn’t here is disgraceful.

I saw MANY copies of this being sold physically at Best Buy, so I know for a fact this game is easier to get than it seems, Nintendo’s forced scarcity is just a way to push people into buying something they would’ve otherwise passed on.

I bought this for the same reason. I’m not crazy about Mario to begin with, but I didn’t wanna miss out on owning this in my collection.

This Christmas I’m getting a mod kit called the G Boy Rev III, a kit designed to turn a Nintendo wii into a handheld that plays all its games digitally. And on that console, I’ll be able to play Mario Sunshine, Mario Galaxy, AND Mario Galaxy 2, all on native hardware for the best latency and frame rate possible, as well as a perfectly suitable emulation of Mario 64.

In other words, I don’t NEED this collection. I bought it BECAUSE it’s limited release. So congrats Nintendo, your scummy business tactics work, but your collection is painfully average.

If you’ve got more willpower than me, be better than me and avoid this one. It’s not worth it.

text: So I did not buy this from Amazon. But I feel like I have to write a review for everyone. I loved Mario 64. Always have and always will. I  beat it around 20 times on Nintendo 64. Maybe 5-10 times on wii and Wii U ( All 120 stars). I consider it as one of the greatest games of all time, Next to goldeneye 007. When this came out I was so excited until I played it. The graphics are the same as I remembered. That’s fine with me. The camera sucks as I’m used to. Again I’m fine with that. That’s the game I’m used to. The thing I can’t get past is the controls. They are either too touchy or non responsive. Again I have beat the game a lot. I know what I’m doing, I know everything about the game. But the way the controls work, it makes it almost unplayable. I’m pretty bummed out about the game because it had potential. But save your money or wait for them to do an update and fix it. Some of the easiest levels are unbeatable or really, really hard. I’m only at 32 stars and not even past level 8. I want to keep playing because I love it, but it’s hard to play when you can’t even wall jump without it being non responsive. Or when you get the flying cap you can’t triple jump. That’s just a few problems. There are many, many more. Hope this helps on your purchase.

title: Objectiviely Fantastic Rereleases of All Time Classics
text:
Super Mario 3D All Stars is a great collection to relive some of Mario's greatest adventures. The collection comes with 3 games that all are built to control on the Switch. Super Mario 64 has added rumble, patches a few bugs and has some quality of life additions. While there isn't things like widescreen for Super Mario 64; Nintendo removed the ugly blur filter that all N64 games have and as a result it looks a lot more smooth and clear for the Nintendo Switch. Something I don't hear a whole lot of people talk about is how this is a version of Super Mario 64 we NEVER got for North America. It's called the "Shindou Version" that like I said about adds rumble support & patches a few things which I must say the HD rumble feels nice everytime Mario performs and action. It isn't distracting and really makes you feel like you're in the game.

Super Mario Sunshine is a game that not everyone is able to play, but now can thanks to this being the first time It's EVER been released on another platform by Nintendo. It now has widescreen support, which is nice but to me I don't feel it's necessary personally. The game is scaled up to 1080p and looks great for being a gamecube game! While Super Mario Sunshine is a rough & challenging game to play to this day, it certainly is a unique experience you won't find anywhere else and I'd say buying this collection alone for Sunshine is worth it due to Gamecube prices skyrocketing!

Super Mario Galaxy has been outfitted to run nearly natively on the Switch console and out of the 3 games has the most work done for it due to the Wii's complicated nature. You can now control the pointer functions using the Joycon and even the pro controller! All of it is motion based and you no longer need a sensor bar to control said pointer. If the pointer gets out of sync, you can easily reset it with a press of a button. Not to mention, motion controls are no longer required to play this game; you can now spin Mario with also just a press of a button.

Overall, I'd say this collection is worth it to relive these great classic games from my childhood. I would drop a star due to in shipping a small portion of my physical copy was damaged but, recently Amazon refunded me $10 due to having per-ordered it and they price matched. Very nice of them so I'm keeping this at 5 stars instead of dropping it by one. The collection might not be for everyone, but I would say if you are young and have always wanted to play one of these 3 all time classics, go for it.

title: The game is fun!
text: The game is a lot of fun!

title: Would be excellent if it had customizable controls
text:
With the addition of controls customization, this would be an easy 5 stars from me. You know these games, you know they’re great, and since you clicked here, you want them in a nice convenient package to play all three on your Switch. If you come into it knowing and accepting this compilation is minimal in terms of extras, you are going to have a great time.

Upon firing up the game, you get a little juxtaposition of Mario obtaining a star/shine sprite in all three games, and it plays the jingle for getting a star in Super Mario Galaxy. Simple, but I like it, and it does a good job at getting you excited to revisit these games.

The game select menu gives you a brief summary of each game, and plays a song picked at random from one of the three soundtracks. Neat touch! You can also access all three soundtracks and pick whichever song you would like to play while in the menu. This is basically the one “extra feature” of the set.

As I mentioned earlier, my biggest complaint is the fact that you can’t customize the controls. The controls are responsive, and are probably the best ones they could have picked as a single control scheme to please everyone, but for people used to the originals, there is just a little bit of getting used to that could have been bypassed if they had some sort of “original controls” option.

For Super Mario 64, I like the higher sensitivity in the joy con sticks to the original N64 analog stick. This makes it easier to turn on a dime, which especially helps for doing the flip jump, which was sometimes difficult to consistently perform in the original.

However, the one part of the game that is MORE difficult to control, as a result of the sensitivity, is aiming the cannon. Thankfully, you’re not on any time limit when doing this, but I found it more difficult to make smaller adjustments to the projectile angle without having it moving way farther than intended. ALSO, most players would probably like this, but the cannon aiming is no longer done with inverted controls, which takes a bit of time for old farts like me to get used to. Again, I know I’m likely in the minority, and it didn’t absolutely ruin the game or anything, but I would have greatly appreciated the option to customize the controls here to my liking.

As for Super Mario Sunshine, you again no longer have inverted controls for aiming your water stream when using F.L.U.D.D. Same point as above: doesn’t ruin the game, but I would have liked the option to play it as I remembered. However, one change is that now there are two different buttons for shooting water. More specifically, to fix your position and shoot, hold R, and to shoot while moving, hold ZR. This is much more precise than the original, in which these distinct shooting options were toggled by how far down you pressed R, which led to a fair number of situations in which you unintentionally employ the wrong style of shooting. I like this change a lot, except for one strange consequence. Since playing requires using ZR, you cannot use a Gamecube controller.

That’s right, you cannot use the controller this game was originally designed for DESPITE THE FACT THAT THE SWITCH SPECIFICALLY ALLOWS YOU TO CONNECT ONE USING AN ADAPTER. What a lost opportunity! Again, this could have been very easily remedied by allowing you to remap this function to a different button that is available on the GameCube controller, or else by simply allowing for a “classic controls” option.

Super Mario Galaxy...well, to be honest, I’m not too far yet, but I don’t have any issues with the default controls! You can easily play with one joy con in each hand to replicate the original feeling of having a Wii remote in one hand, and the nunchuck in the other. In addition, for those who dislike motion controls, you can now perform the essential spin action with the y button instead of shaking the joy con, though the latter also serves this function if you prefer. Again, this shows how the other ports could have been truly excellent by simply allowing the player to choose how they would most like to control our favorite plumber.

As for the rest of the details about how these ports are handled, I have no complaints. The graphics show some age, but have been smoothed out a bit, most noticeably in Super Mario 64, which looks much less “polygonal.” The frame rate is also higher and more consistent, which again is most noticeable in Super Mario 64. I swore at first that the game speed must have been higher! Likewise, there have been fixes to slowdown issues noticeable in Super Mario 64 and Super Mario Sunshine. Super Mario Sunshine now has subtitles (can be turned off if you prefer), which is great because there are moments in the game where the mixing on the voice tracks are not very clear. I was NEVER able to understand what those cops told Mario after leaving the cell when I played the original! I think some of the sound effects in Super Mario 64, like Mario’s “wha!” when jumping, have a higher pitch than the original, but I might just be crazy. Even if I’m not, you’d have to be a pretty picky originalist to care. Oh, and no more “so long, King Bowser!” when you throw him by the tail in Super Mario 64. A more noticeable change, but again, it would be a nitpick to complain about, and people who know what I’m talking about know exactly why Nintendo would opt to change this. I haven’t played through these games entirely, so there might be other slight changes, but I trust that they would be trivial.

So there you have it, all three games and what you can expect from them. No save states, no display or audio customizability, no additional unlockables or challenges, no extensive galleries or fun facts (aside from the blurbs for the games on the select screen), and most importantly to me, no options for changing the controls. However, all games are very cleanly emulated, have responsive controls, and are still a blast to play. For some, this is the only realistic option to play these games, and buying this package is a no-brainer. As for those who already own some or all of the original games and consoles, you’re probably the best judge of how much value you’ll get from this set. Just remember not to wait too long. As you may already know, it won’t be available for purchase physically or digitally after March 2021. I really, really wish that Nintendo didn’t arbitrarily impose this limited availability for people who might want to wait longer or aren’t Switch owners yet, but that’s another story.

title: Great being able to play these games on the switch, but some weird decisions from nintendo.
text:
Let me start by saying I don't mind that this is just a couple emulators that Nintendo threw together under a $60 price tag. In my opinion I'm paying for the ability to play these great games on my switch wherever I take it. Yes I can get emulators for all these games on a computer, but lugging a computer or laptop around on travel is far less convenient than using a switch. That combined with the how well Mario Galaxy works with the pro controller/joycons, you can't really replicate that in emulation.

All 3 games seem to play well. The updated sprites and resolution look nice especially when displayed on a TV. Where things start to fall apart are the control setups. I'm not sure why they did this, but they bound A and B to the same buttons in the games. This is really weird and feels unnatural. They were obviously trying to make these games utilize all the functions of the pro/joycon controllers. They utilize the thumb stick buttons to replace certain things which is also quite weird when going from playing these games on their original console, to this emulator.

By far and away my biggest problem is with sunshine. I was a biiiig sunshine fan when I was growing up and I still have 2 copies of it for my gamecube. I guess I never really realized that the controls for sunshine were inverted, I just got used to it and now whenever I play it my mind automatically goes back into "sunshine mode" and I play fine with the inversion. I understand that most people are not used to this so making them default to non-inverted controls makes sense, but why not make in an option? They obviously messed with the bindings already to un-invert the controls so why not just make it toggleable? This makes sunshine pretty unplayable. I'm pretty hesitant to start playing it now cause I don't want to get super used to the non-inverted controls and then be terrible at the original version. Another huge issue is the non-existence of gamecube controller support. Nintendo already makes gamecube controllers and adapters for the switch, so why not let mario sunshine work with a gamecube controller? Again, they went through the effort to remap buttons so why not keep the mode compatible with gamecube? One more thing that is really weird is that the B button is now mapped to jump, so the muscle memory of hitting A->B to jump and dive (which is a very used movement mechanic in this game) is gone. That and the over-the-shoulder cam is now bound to right stick click which is really foreign.

If you haven't played any of the original games, and this is the first time you are getting introduced to them, this is a great deal. However, if you have played them before, or are even huge fans, expect some disappointment and weird button mappings until you get used to them.

title: A Decent anniversary celebration with minor tweaks.
text: If you don't own these on any other platform this is a great way to revisit these beloved classics. Mario 64 is almost tripled it's original resolution while holding a stable 30 frames per second with this being a port of the revised "Shindou pak taiou" 1997 edition the backwards vault slide glitch was fixed along with the "So long gay bowser" meme but most textures are unchanged. Super Mario Sunshine seems to have had the most attention with more vibrant colors all around as well as the higher resolution resulting in a much less blurry image. However this game also runs at 30 frames per second and the classic GameCube controls have been slightly altered due to differences when compared with the Switch's Joycons, even when using an adapter (so you can no longer change the water pressure.) Last but not least Mario Galaxy looks sharper than ever with the boost in resolution and transitions to modern displays quite smoothly, motion controls are integrated very well and this is an all around smooth 60fps experience. The soundtrack from all 3 games are also included.

title: A great selection of games in a mediocre collection
text:
Super Mario 64, Super Mario Sunshine, and Super Mario Galaxy are all fantastic games and this is their best official release they've ever had. Sunshine and Galaxy both benefit immensely from the bump up to HD, and Sunshine in particular benefits especially from the addition of widescreen. Mario 64, on the other hand, has not had many improvements made. Unlike Sunshine, 64 is still in 4:3 aspect ratio, not widescreen, and its frame rate has seen no improvements. There are much better unofficial ways to play Mario 64 these days and unfortunately Nintendo's own version falls wildly short of those. All three games are great nonetheless, and as far as official releases go, there are no other options that are better than this.

The collection itself, however, is almost comically barebones. For a collection featuring three of Nintendo's biggest games they've ever made, I truly would've expected some more love and care to be placed in its bonus features. It offers no behind the scenes information, no concept art, no looks into cut content, no additional modes or quality of life improvements for the games included, nothing like any of that. It offers a *single* bonus feature, and that's the ability to listen to the official soundtrack releases of the three included games. It falls short of other, less expensive collections out there today, such as the Megaman Legacy collections, the Disney Afternoon Collection, or even Nintendo's *own* Kirby's Dream Collection from eight years ago, which all feature loads of interesting and valuable side content to enjoy other than just the games themselves.

The games themselves, to me, are worth the price of admission- but for a full $60 retail game, released to celebrate the anniversary of the most famous video game character in the world, I would've expected Nintendo to put a lot more effort into making this package seem truly special.

title: It’s good. Don’t expect too much out of Nintendo.
text:
You know, it’s a good deal. Three quality games. Don’t get your hopes up. They are not remasters, just enhanced versions. If you’ve never played any of these games before, pick it up if you can. Expecting too much out of Nintendo is the wrong thing to do in this case. It’s a fine, fun game. This game is not a remaster. They are emulated copies.

Controls get some getting used to.

Again, it’s a great collection. Getting to play Super Mario 64 for the first time is certainly an experience. Sunshine is also quite an experience. While Galaxy has some wonky controls it’s just as good as I remember.

Again, it’s a good collection of games. Pick it up while you can, if you can. Don’t give into the no-good scalpers.

That is all.

title: Nostalgic
text:
Alright, here's the thing.

I know this has been getting a lot of hate from a lot of people who are frustrated with Nintendo's lack of polish / design choices for this particular retro release, and / or the $60 price tag. I understand and completely support those people.

However, for me, this is everything I was looking for. I have never finished any of these three games, never owned the first two, but have played countless hours of them. I have no retro systems and no means to play these games other than digging around to find old N64s, GameCubes or Wiis that still work, controllers to play them with and the games themselves. For my own purposes, this package was a godsend, as I finally have the ability to try my hand at speedrunning Mario 64 (albeit without BLJ, since this uses the updated Japanese version that patched that out - RIP Gay Bowser), to play Sunshine all the way through and to show my kids these incredible games that defined a generation of gaming.

Is this perfect for everyone? No, but it was what I've personally been waiting for, so 5 stars from me.

title: Collection of Good Games
text: This is very much a collection of good games and NOT a good collection of games. Nintendo did the bare minimum to make these games playable and sold the bundle for $60. It's pathetic honestly.

title: Lazy port ruins these classic games
text:
Fun games ruined by a bare bones port.

Most collection games come with a bunch of goodies, a way for developers to show off how proud they are of their games and as an extra for diehard fans. What does this port have? Does it let you play as Luigi in Mario 64? Does it have an unlockable Mario galaxy 2? Are there any other extras cut from the original games?

Nope, just music, a tiny blurb about each game, and a look at the box art. Wow so great, I’m glad I can listen to music from my switch instead of using my iPhone.

Did they fix the awful camera in Super Mario 64? Nope in fact using the thumb stick to move the camera is more awkward because they keep the old c buttons so you gotta move the thumb stick one way and then take your finger off the stick and then move the stick again.

Not to mention the pointer gets lost all the time in Mario galaxy (something the wii version didn’t have much of an issue with).

The good thing about the games is that they look good on a modern television but did they actually update the graphics so the games look like Mario odyssey? Or even Mario galaxy? Nope super Mario 64 still looks blocky.

So all in all don’t spend your money on this game. Don’t support Nintendo’s lazy port job.

title: Childhood nostalgia, now in HD
text:
I'm 28 years old. These three games were some of the defining ones of my life at different points. And now they've come in HD to the Nintendo Switch, and I couldn't be any more ecstatic.

Some people might complain that these games (particularly SM64) weren't remade akin to Spyro/Crash/etc trilogies. In my opinion, that doesn't detract from anything at all. Would it have been nice? Sure, but these games are some of the best games of all time, and the original graphics create that nostalgia that I feel Nintendo was going for with this compilation.

I can't wait to sink my time into all 3 of these classics again, and I'm grateful that the switch now has almost all of Mario's greatest games on it. Here's hoping Galaxy 2 is around the corner in some form!

title: Expectations were met

Would I have preferred to see these games remade in Odyssey's engine? Yes, Absolutely. Nintendo didn't go above and beyond with this collection, but that didn't stop me from having fun with it.

So I did,I restarted the game. Same thing. Then I restarted the system. Same thing. I completely reset my system for the sole purpose of playing this game.I tried to find the corrupt data and re download it but nothing works. I really don't understand why I got this error. title: Great games, lazy and greedy Nintendo
text:
Whether Mario All Stars 3D is worth it will differ among people. Objectively, it isn't. It's $60 for a fairly barebones emulation of 3 very old games. For $40 you can get full on remakes like Crash Trilogy, Spyro, Tony Hawk Pro Skater, Destroy All Humans!, and Mafia Definitive Edition. Nintendo knows a collection of some of their best Mario games would sell, so they did the least amount of effort for maximum profit and even made it a limited time offer to salt the wound even further.

Why did I review it 5 stars? Mario Galaxy is not a complete emulation. It runs natively on the Switch’s cpu. This means 60 FPS smooth buttery goodness with graphics and gameplay that hold up extremely well in 2020. It’s one of my favorite games of all time, and for me I know I will get $60 of enjoyment out of having it on my switch alongside Sunshine and 64. It’s just a shame Nintendo didn’t go the extra mile to make a truly special anniversary package.

title: Classic Super Mario 3D games in the Nintendo Switch
text: Overall for fans of the Super Mario 3D games for the Nintendo 64, GameCube, Nintendo Wii classics, Super Mario 3D all stars is a dream come true especially for those who got to enjoy these classic games before they arrived in the Switch. The game features the music and other special features which allows you to transition from the 3 different games and lets you build your progress as you go. The games are well adapted with the Switch controllers in comparison to the original Nintendo 64, GameCube and Nintendo Wii versions as they managed to brilliantly put the games together so you could play them all with the Switch controller and enjoy all 3 games without having to switch to a different type of control. Beautiful graphics, music, game play will keep you on the edge. For all those who are Nintendo fan and fan of the Super Mario games from Nintendo, this Switch special edition of Super Mario 3D stars is a must have for all gamers and fans of video games in general.

title: Great to have these games portably, bare-bones package.
text:
This is hard to rate.

If you've never played these games... I don't know if I'd recommend this for $60, but you will likely never have a chance to purchase it for less.

Super Mario 64 is a landmark 3D platformer, but it shows its age. The controls and the camera do not place nice together, especially in cramped spaces. Most of my deaths have come from sudden camera shifts, or Mario walking off a ledge because he'll sometimes move in a semi-circle when he turns around.

The level design is incredible, the sound design is some of the most satisfying of any of the Mario series, the game oozes creativity, but if you didn't grow up with early 3D platformers it's hard to recommend. I would heavily encourage anyone to give it a try, but not for $60, and not even as part of a $60 package. A Hat in Time and Spyro Reignited much easier to recommend than Mario 64.

Super Mario Sunshine is really charming, but it's bland next to Mario 64. It's another game that I'd heartily recommend giving a try, but not for $60. Everyone's mileage varies with this game. The camera is pretty unruly. It has some glitchy segments that haven't been fixed in this edition.

For my personal experience, I've done a 120 star run of Mario 64, and I'm about to finish another one on this collection. That can be tedious at points, but it's satisfying enough for me to stick with it. I will probably never get all the shine sprites. Some missions are just that frustrating to me. I like Sunshine, but I don't love it.

Mario Galaxy is easily the best game on here, and while I know some of the other reviews complained about it still using motion controls, this version at least has the spin move - your main attack - mapped to a button.

I liked Galaxy back on the Wii, but I was so allergic to motion controls that even though it was obviously a great game I never got very far. Playing it with a pro controller takes some getting used to because you have to shift the whole controller when you need to move the pointer on the screen, but it doesn't take long before it feels fairly natural, and being able to do the spin without the waggle has increased my enjoyment of the game immensely.

This is, bar none, the best these games have ever looked in a retail release. These are the definitive versions of all three games on console.

By others means... Is a different matter.

There's ways to play Mario 64 at 60fps, 1080p widescreen, with mods that drastically improve the camera. That Nintendo gave us Mario 64 at 30fps in 720p with some improved textures is disappointing, to say the least. The source code is out in the wild. Fans have made fantastic remasters that run on Switch hardware. If you're a first-timer, I would recommend those ports in a heartbeat over this. If you already own a copy of Mario 64 on original hardware or on the Wii, I don't see any reason to pick up 3D All Stars for this.

Super Mario Sunshine runs about as well as it does on the Dolphin emulator. On the one hand, I'm really glad they put the effort in and that we can play Sunshine on a modern platform. On the other, it feels so low-effort.

Galaxy probably had the fewest changes, but it needed the least amount of work. It's honestly a masterpiece. If you're a newcomer, it justifies the price tag all on its own. At 1080p, it looks like it was made for current hardware and plays like a dream on the Switch.

If you love Mario, get this. It's a collector's item. Even if you never intend to play it, it's a piece of history. If you loved the games when you were a kid and don't own them anymore, these are the versions to get. If you played them to death or own other versions, nothing here is worth rushing to the store to get it. If you're still on the fence, don't bother.

The only extras in this are the soundtracks for each game. It's nice to have, but I'm never going to play them on my Switch. I would've rather gotten codes for Spotify or Amazon.

The lack of an in-game art gallery, unlockable commercials, concept sketches, etc. is extremely disappointing. As far as I'm concerned, Sonic Mega Collection back on the Gamecube set the gold standard for retro game collections, and this is nowhere close to being on the same level.

The omission of Galaxy 2 and 3D Land also bother me. If one or both of those games were included, this would be an absolute no-brainer.

Mario is popular enough I think you already know whether this is for you.

title: Great game, no support for Switch and game-breaking bugs
text:
This is a great game. My daughter loves playing it. Everyone and their brother knows it's a great game.

I am writing this review to warn parents that the company that makes the game, Mojang, cannot seem to be bothered to care about the switch version. Until they fix the Switch version all reviews should be 1 star.

There are game-breaking problems that you would expect to only see in the worst games you can find on the market. It is beyond me why this company can't fix these problems because they are very basic. Do they have trained wombats doing their coding? The problems also seem to change over time, but are equally bad.

For a long time, the switch version had terrible scene loading and glitch problems. These seemed to finally be repaired by some update.

Now the switch version, for some reason, takes 5-10 minutes to load your Microsoft Account info, which you need to play online. If you attempt to load a game before this info loads, it just doesn't place the character creation content into the game (which many refer to as "skins"). This is the hair, clothing, styles for your character. More often than not the "skin" info never loads regardless of time waited.

Now if I were to play Minecraft, I'd be patient and wait for the stuff to load, and whatever I don't care what my character looks like I'll just mine or build. To my child, and many children, part of the fun is making their character look cool. My child changes the way the character looks like once every 15 minutes. My child is old enough to start the game themselves, but not really patient enough to wait for the "maybe it will load eventually, maybe it won't" character skins. This causes massive frustration for children. My child essentially doesn't want to play the game because they can't change their character most of the time. So that was $$ I just threw in the trash.

*If* you have a child, you will also understand how frustrating it is when their friend who is playing online with them can change their character and they can't. Since the "skin" loading is completely random as to whether it will work, and rarely works, you are also spending time trying "help" and to reload the game 10 times to see if it will load this time. Now you just wasted an hour and half.

All of this is ridiculous. Character creation is really basic, you just load content. NO, and I mean NO other game I play on the Switch or anywhere else has this basic, newb, fundamental problem. Why is this basic function not fixable by Mojang? Trained wombats.

Avoid all this headache and buy the game on some other platform.

For comparison, none of my other Switch games suffer from this issue. They all play seamlessly.

title: Nintendo Switch Online Doesn't Work
text:
I purchased 2 copies of this version of Minecraft to play with my son who lives in another state. After having trouble figuring out how Minecraft was going to work under the Nintendo Online system I went ahead and bought two versions and started fiddling with it. That's when I noticed how poor the system works with 2 big problems.

1. The game in theory, will let people (each with their own Nintendo Online account) to play together without using Microsoft Realms. I thought this would be a godsend, but it seems Nintendo hasn't done a great job aligning the features and my son soon realized that you can create a new world and both of us can play on it, but when we log out he can no longer join that server. Doesn't matter if I make the server/world, or if he does, you seem to only get 1 play out of it. I looked at NAT types, I've tried port forwarding, and slew of other things. Nintendo/Mojang support is not helpful either with this problem apparently plaguing other users.

2. The game itself is very buggy considering how it seems Nintendo Online handle latency and other issues. I found myself disconnected on a few occasions, or situations where I could no longer see my son's avatar even though he was right in front of me (I witnessed this over facetime). Other issues like landscape (FOV) not appearing seem pretty common in multiplayer.

The singleplayer is fine and the controls once you get used to them work great, but the primary reason I got 2 copies of this was so I could play online and that feature is doesn't work. If the problem can be resolved I'll change my review.

Update: 6+ months later and the Nintendo Online feature still does the same thing and I've had to continue paying for a microsoft realm for us to both play on.

title: 2gb Limit of Gameplay on Switch
text:
Only allows up to 2gb of gameplay regardless of space available on your switch or sd card. This makes the game literally impossible to keep playing. You'll be playing then abruptly receive an error message reading
"you are almost out of data storage space". At that point you'll no longer be able to play your saved games. There is no way around this nor does it mention anywhere that this exists.

Don't buy this game.

title: Mi mejor experiencia con mi hijo
text:
[[VIDEOID:4c54512fa76db6b8a74f1abf51092631]] MINECRAFT es el LEGO DIGITAL, al jugar con mi hijo me recordó cuando era pequeño. Aprendí que Minecraft tiene cinco modos de juego (supervivencia, creativo, extremo, espectador y aventura) todos ellos tienen en común la recolección de recursos, diseño de objetos, construcción y combate.

Así por ejemplo, para sobrevivir, los niños tienen no sólo que construir edificios de forma creativa, objetos -como un pico o una estufa para cocinar - lo que significa que deben explorar y recoger materias primas. Asimismo, al caer la noche, deben defender sus bienes de arañas, zombis y esqueletos que querrán arrebatárselos.

title: Too many Crashes!
text: I bought this game card for my Nintendo in February of this year, and ever since then I have been experiencing a plethora of issues and crashes. First off, there will be times where I will leave the game and when I come back my profile won’t pop up leaving me to either wait and see what happens(which usually leaves me waiting like 5 minutes) or go through Microsoft and log in again(which can be so annoying). Another issue I have is with online playing otherwise known as Realms. There are so many bugs I don’t even know where to start, so I’ll just give you the cliff notes. There are times where the blocks won’t break or blocks that I didn’t click on will disappear, times where I will randomly lose health for no reason, and when I have to log back on the game(due to a situation I will get to later) some of my items will disappear, along with many many more. My biggest issue with this game card out of everything is that I will be playing on realms and all of the sudden the game will glitch out and tell me that my server is disconnected. I have to log back out of the game and come back in(sometimes having to restart the entire console) which can be literal torture due to the previous issues I have mentioned before. I have absolutely no explanation as to why this game card has so many positive reviews other than the brand selling this paying them off because there is no way they are genuinely enjoying this glitchy mess. I write this dissertation to say that you should not let the positive reviews fool you, don’t be an idiot like me who is now stuck with this mess; turn far, far away and find another seller that can give you what you have paid for because clearly Microsoft can’t.
